PARIS, Feb. 26 (UP)--An Italian commercial delegation headed by Senator Amedeo Giannini arrived here today to begin negotiations for a revised Franco-Italian trade agreement.

ROME, Feb. 26 (UP)--Approval yesterday of the beatification of the venerable Gioacchina de Vedruna and the venerable Philippine Duchesne, who lived twenty-four years in the United States, way announced today by the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The seven new C-type passenger and cargo ships being built for the round-the-world service of the American President Lines, Ltd., are to bear the names of Presidents Adams, Monroe, Jackson, Van Buren, Polk, Hayes and Garfield, the Maritime Commission announced today. LONDON, Feb. 26--President Roosevelt, it was reliably stated here today, has granted the request of the Polish Government in exile that Summer Welles receive Polish officials during his visit to France. MADRID, Feb. 26--The last two American prisoners of war known to be still in captivity in Spain are en route to Seville and will sail for the United States in two weeks, it was learned today at the United States Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The House Democratic majority stuck by its guns today in fighting off a spirited Republican attempt to abolish the proposed housing census in connection with the sixteenth decennial census, and then all members joined in passing, without a record vote, the $90,069,139 First Deficiency Bill.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP)--Pooling of the power of the British and French Empires in this war was disclosed here today to extend to nearly complete collaboration in purchase of foodstuffs. Trading in listed bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was of a dull and routine character. Except for the few issues that responded to some show of speculative activity, the market reflected no shaking-off of the lethargy that has ruled in recent sessions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--The Senate confirmed today President Roosevelt's nomination of James J. McEntee of New Jersey to be director of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

The Eighth Avenue Temple and Union Temple basketball teams gained the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan A.A.U. basketball championship with victories at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Eighth Avenue beat the Montana F.C. of Staten Island, 38 to 25, and Union Temple topped Boys Welcome Hall, 39 to 29.

PEIPING, China, Feb. 26--Wang Keh-mill, head of the Peiping Provisional Government, is going by plane to Nanking tomorrow or Wednesday for a wind-up meeting on the United Council, which is expected to solve all pending problems of the Peiping and Nanking regimes prior to the establishing of Wang Ching-wei's so-called Central Government.
HONG KONG, Feb. 26(AP)--Japanese military dispatches today reported Chinese were massing in Kwangsi Province in the south for another attempt to recapture Nanning, the provincial capital.

Edwin McArthur, young American conductor, will make his debut with the Metropolitan Opera Association on its Spring tour, directing "Tristan and Isolde" in Boston on April 1. The cast will include Kirsten Flagstad, for whom Mr. McArthur frequently has appeared as piano accompanist in recital, and Lauritz Melchior.

Offering to the public will be made today of 35,651 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Beech Aircraft Corporation by Neelands Platte of New York and Tifft Brothers of Springfield. The offering represents 10,000 shares ...

BUFFALO, Feb. 26 (AP)--Justice Raymond C. Vaughan in Supreme Court today dismissed the suit of a C.I.O meat cutter for back wages covered by an unexpired contract with the Jacob Dold Packing Company. The suit waa filed by ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Interest here in the message delivered today by Summer Welles, Under-Secretary of State, from President Roosevelt to Premier Mussolini, centered less on its consents than on whether a similar message would be delivered to Chancellor Hitler.
Steel operations this week are scheduled at 65.9 per cent of capacity, a dcrease of 1.2 points, or 1.8 per cent, from last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Selection of a blue-ribbon jury and two alternate jurors to hear evidence in the first-degree murder trial of Ernest Walter Kehler, 24year-old boxer, was completed at 11:05 o'clock last night in Kings ...

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 26--This old Northern New England snow center returned to normal today after having served as host to the country's most distinguished "riders" and to some 15,000 enthusiasts at the national championships yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--The Department of Agriculture reported today that deliveries of direct-consumption sugar by manufacturers and importers in January amounted to 382,696 short tons, raw value.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 26-- Earry (Cookie) Lavagetto, one of the Dodger holdouts from California, arrived today, conferred with President Larry MacPhail, but failed to sign his contract. Cookie didn't get into uniform and spent his first day at the ball park watching the strenuous exercising of his team-mates.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP)-- Dr. Mary Mills Patrick, founder and president emerita of the Istanbul Woman's College in Turkey, formerly the Constantinople Woman's College, died of a heart attack here yesterday at the age of 89.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UP)--Mrs. Louise de Koven Bowen, whose philanthropies supported famed Hull House during its early years, celebrated her eighty-first birthday today. Thousands of congratulatory messages from the rich and the poor poured into her home.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The United States commercial attache in Berlin has estimated that Germany's currency circulation has increased 33 per cent since the outbreak of the war.

Ambrose Monell Steinert, chief of the Division of Receipts and Disbursements in the City Treasurer's office, died of pneumonia on Sunday at the Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens, after a brief illness. He was 56 years old. His home was at 40-41 166th Street, Flushing.

Ending rumors prevalent since war broke out in Europe that there would be a disastrous "blackout" in the international area of the 1940 New York World's Fair, the Fair Corporation issued yesterday an official "factual review," disclosing that the impressive array of foreign exhibits adjoining the Court of Peace would be virtually intact.
The American Export liner Excambion arrived yesterday at Jersey City from Mediterranean ports with ninety-one passengers.

Under the Wagner act, an employer is obliged to put into writing any agreement that may be reached through collective bargaining with his employes, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 26 (UP)--The United States destroyers Trippe and Stack arrived here today on a shakedown cruise. The cruisers, each of 1,500 tons, were built under the 1934-35 program.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26--Led by the $100,605 salary of Martin W. Clement, president, the total remuneration received by directors and officers from the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and its subsidiaries in 1939 was $541,462, according to a proxy statement mailed to stockholders in connection with the ninety-third annual meeting on April 9.
LONDON, Feb. 26--The International Tin Committee today fixed the export quota for the second quarter of 1940 at 80 per cent, against the present level of 120 per cent.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (UP)--Steve Martin of Miami Beach and Young Allen of Macon, Ga., battled to a draw tonight in their ten-round heavyweight fight at the Beach Arena. Martin, who won an unpopular decision from the Georgia youth here three weeks ago, weighed 204 pounds. Allen scaled 186 .

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--January factory sales of automobiles, according to the Department of Commerce, were lower than in December, but substantially better than in January, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--For some time the go-ahead signal on the thirdterm draft movement has been burning green and bright. Members of the Cabinet, Governors, Senators and machine bosses like Mayor Kelly of Chicago, Mayor Hague of Jersey City and Leader Sullivan of Tammany Hall have urged that the President be conscripted for another term, without a deterrent word from Mr. Roosevelt.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries report a net profit of $5,797,632 for the nine months ended on Jan. 31, 1940, equal to $1.68 a common share after preferred dividends.

This country has reached the point where any further increase in taxation will mean an increase in unemployment, Representative Bruce Barton declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Merchants Association in the Hotel Astor.

MADRID, Feb. 26--A shipment containing nearly 700 golf clubs with a large number of bags and repair materials, presented to Spanish golfers by devotees of the game in the New York area, arrived today. It was turned over ...

Under the influence of active mill covering and foreign buying, prices on the Cotton Exchange here continued yesterday the upward movement which got under way last week and ended with gains of 1 to 6 points. After liquidating 2,000 bales at each point advance, a prominent spot firm withdrew its selling orders.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb., 26 --Three vital units of the Yankee baseball machine officially became holdouts today as Marse Joe McCarthy's squad inaugurated the training campaign for what is expected to be the fifth straight year of its American League domination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--The House Appropriations Committee brought forth today a bill to supply various Federal departments and agencies with money they will need between now and next June 30. One of the items was: "For repairs of arsenals, army, 5 cents." It was one of a long list of small appropriations to wipe out overdrafts by departments on previous appropriations.

The Metropolitan Section of the American Society of Civil Engineers is to unveil in the near future in the City Hall station of the B.M.T. a bronze tablet in honor of New York City's first subway and of its creator, Alfred Ely ...

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26-- Princeton's varsity gymnasts defeated Dartmouth, 41-13, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet tonight. Paul Condit placed first in tumbling and the rope climb for the Tigers. The Princeton freshmen gymnasts downed Union Hill High, 42--12.
Last Summer Martin T. Manton, sometime senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here, was convicted of corruption on the bench. He was sentenced to pay a fine ...

After an absence of several seasons, Gil Valeriano, Spanish tenor, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. Since his last local appearance, he has concertized in Germany, England, Italy and Spain, and sung with the Opera-Comique in Paris.

The Neediest Cases Fund received two contributions amounting to $4 yesterday, brining its total to $262,865.71, One was an anonymous gift of $3; the other was a contribution of $1 from "Keech--In Memory of David."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today applications by the New York Curb Exchange to extend unlisted trading privileges to first mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series ...

The Citizens Budget Commission expressed dismay yesterday over departmental budget requests showing an increase of $56,402,798 above present allowances and warned that the city must cut its expenses to meet its income.

Faced with an increasing flight of capital as well as with the problem of settling an unfavorable trade balance, the Swedish Government has abandoned informal restraints in controlling gold and foreign exchange in favor of an official tightening of such controls.
HAVANA, Feb. 26--"Springtime for Henry," with Edward Everett Horton in the leading role, opened a three-day engagement here tonight at the Alkazar Theatre.

Rising 43 per cent over last year, Buick domestic retail sales in the second ten days of this month were 5,184 new cars, the company announced yesterday. Used car sales totaled 23,133 for the first twenty days of the month.

Hitler himself thinks his chances of winning the war are 100 per cent, but there are some American observers abroad who give him only a 55-to-45.

The De Grasse, the only French passenger ship in transatlantic service, arrived here yesterday morning with an additional gun at the stern but without the gun that has stood on a platform at her bow on her last three voyages.

A number of the units figuring in yesterday's business leasing reports were full floors and other large areas of space. A wide range of business enterprises were listed, the fur and apparel trades being well represented.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--The Senate tonight advanced to third reading the Wicks bill giving the State Transit Commission the right to regulate service on the subway systems in New York City after unification. The companion Thompson bill is on the third-reading calendar in the Assembly for tomorrow and is expected to be passed then.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP)-- The Maritime Commission said today that the American Presidents Line has selected the names for the new C-E passenger-freighter vessels now under construction.
Taxpayer's were warned yesterday by the Bureau of Internal Revenue that the bureau has at its command "many sources for checking up on delinquent taxpayers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Commerce Department's seasonally adjusted index of dollar sales of chain groceries in January remained at about the December level of 109, a figure which has been maintained, with one exception, for five consecutive months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Three omnibus bills to authorize $412,638,600 for navigation, flood control and multiple-purpose waterway projects were drafted today by a Senate commerce subcommittee.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 26-- The Finns today admitted that they had abandoned their Koivisto forts. This is the most depressing news received here since the war began. Even if it does not necessarily mean that Viborg's fate is sealed, it places that city in a situation more serious than ever before.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The Yankees should receive new, unlooked-for but welcome batting strength this season, unless all ordinary signs fail.

ROME, Feb. 26--United States Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles delivered "an autographed message" from President Roosevelt to Premier Mussolini this afternoon. Thus within a day of his arrival in Europe he has put an end to the accepted version that his trip is purely informative.

A program has been worked out by school, court and subway officials to save a large number of high school students from arrests and police records for using slugs in the turnstiles of the transportation systems, it was learned yesterday. The plan also is designed to help students "along paths of honest and proper behavior."

Acting Fire Commissioner Elmer Mustard canceled retirement orders yesterday affecting Fire Chief John J. McElligott and six high officials of the Fire Department, and directed the men to report for duty at the usual time tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26--Herbert Lincoln Clark, a governor of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and partner in E.W. Clark Co., century-old investment house, died tonight in Bryn Mawr Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.

Trailing at 0--3 and 15--40 in the deciding set, Ladislav Hecht, former Czecho-Slovak Davis Cup player, collected his forces to defeat Chauncey Depew Steele Jr. of New York yesterday in the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The score was 1--6, 6--3, 6--4.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 26--With John Hultsch, Ray Stan and Milt Winch accounting for 38 of their team's points, Drew University's quintet downed the Rutgers College of Pharmacy tossers, 50 to 30, tonight. Hultsch and Stan each made 13 points. Winch's 12 markers enabled him to break the Drew scoring record. He now has 204 points, compiled in ten games.
Three new directors and a new member of the national committee of the American Civil Liberties Union were chosen yesterday at a weekly meeting of the union's board of directors.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 26 (AP)-- Purdue clinched at least a share of the Big Ten basketball championship tonight by defeating Iowa, 50 to 29, as Indiana was smothered, 44 to 26, at Ohio State.

PARIS, Feb. 26--Further progress was made today toward drafting the coordinated economic program that was discussed twice last week by the Cabinet. Premier Edouard Daladier met for more than three hours with the Ministers directly concerned.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 26 (AP)--Rumania tonight announced an increase of 12 to 40 per cent on railway freight rates on most exports, including oil consigned to Germany.

Directors of the American Rolling Mill Company ordered yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share on account of arrears on the 4 per cent preferred stock, payable on April 15. This will reduce the amount of dividends in arrears on that date to $2.12 each on 450,000 shares of $100 par value.

BERGEN, Norway, Feb. 26--Information was received here today of a naval engagement between French and British vessels and two German ships off Petsamo. The report was unconfirmed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26(AP)--Mrs. Gerald P. Nye, wife of the North Dakota Senator, intends to seek a divorce. She said today that the petition would be filed this week, but would not discuss details. Mr. Nye was out of the city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--A check of leading Chicago department stores today, following the disclosure by the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank that January department store sales for the city were 13.0 per cent ahead of last year, found a fairly general belief that February was maintaining an equally good pace.
PARIS, Feb. 26--"She eats like a butterfly" will no longer be a compliment in view of a paper read today before the French Academy of Sciences by Professor Pointier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)--Secretary Wallace told the Senate Appropriations Committee today that failure to vote farm parity funds "or their equivalent" might seriously hamper crop-control programs and create new price-depressing surpluses.

PARIS, Feb. 26--"Increased activity of contact units on various points of the West Front between the Moselle and the Saar" was reported in this morning's French High Command communique. During the day confirmation was given that the rhythm of the war was consistently increasing.

Exclusive of stocks already on hand, public consumption of coffee in France for the first four months of the European war has been reduced to 50 per cent of normal, it was disclosed here yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 26 (AP)-- A left to the jaw gave Paul Junior, 137, Lewiston, a knockout victory over Emil Joseph, 135, Pittsburgh, Pa., in the sixth round of their scheduled ten-round boxing bout tonight. Joseph had been on the floor nine times before he went down for the full count.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 26-- Edwin Van Keuren, supervising principal of schools here, resigned tonight at a hearing of the Board of Education called to consider charges against him of incompetency and neglect of duty.

Standard Investing Corporation reports a net asset value of $25.15 per share of preferred stock at Dec. 31, 1939, against $21.42 a share on the same stock a year before.

Princess Paul Sapieha, the former Virgilia Peterson Ross, an American short-story writer and book reviewer before her marriage to a Pole, has written an account of six years in Poland that Carrick Evans will publish as "Polish Passage."

Irving Eldridge, 132 Bronx, won the verdict from Jimmy Vaughn, 135 , Cleveland, in their return eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 3,000 last night. Vaughn triumphed two weeks ago.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26-- Coach Tad Wieman outlined plans for Spring practice to more than sixty Princeton football candidates at a meeting tonight. The Tigers will hold drills for freshmen from March 19 to March 30. The regular sessions for the varsity and cubs are slated from Anril 8 to April 27.

LONDON, Feb. 27--Major Gen. A. G.L. McNaughton, commander of the Canadian Overseas Forces, took over the administration of the Aldershot Command today to hold it for six days while Lieut. Gen. C. N. Broad goes on a short leave.

Among the better story-tellers in basketball circles is Joe Lapchick, coach of the St. John's team, which came so close to inflicting the first defeat of the season on the highflying N.Y.U. squad last week. Years of service with the Celtics have supplied lanky Joe with court lore that never fails to fascinate his listeners.

Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate, who was appointed to the bench in Brooklyn by Mayor La Guardia a week ago, was sworn in yesterday by Justice Matthew J. Troy, who was elevated to Special Sessions at the same time and whose post Magistrate Ramsgate will fill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission within the next week or two will initiate integration proceedings involving the major utility holding company systems, it was learned authoritatively today.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--The attack on the Federal Social Security Board for having held up Social Security funds due New York State, made on the Assembly floor last week by Assemblyman Wadsworth was answered tonight by Assemblyman Robert F. Wagner Jr.

J.P. Leo Jr., top-seeded player, representing the New York Athletic Club, captured the National Squash Tennis Association Class B championship yesterday when he defeated A.M. Moody of the Yale Club in the final match at the Harvard Club, 18--15, 15--4, 15--17, 15--8.

Elisha Walker, the banker, has agreed to serve as treasurer of the Friends of Merey Hospital, Hempstead, L.I., succeeding the late Clarence H. Mackay, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Walker is chairman of the board of the Beekman Street Hospital. The Friends of Mercy Hospital, of which Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff is president, will hold its annual ball Friday evening at the Garden City Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The House Rules Committee today gave right of way for action on the floor tomorrow toward a $20,000,000 loan to Finland through consideration of the Senate-approved bill raising the revolving fund of the Export-Import Bank from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000.
Dr. Robert Maxwell Franklin has resold to Martin J. Furlong the former estate of Mrs. Edith G. Verfield, in Carmel, Putnam County, which he purchased last July.

The favorite challenge to those who believe that it is time to bring a runaway budget under control in Washington is, "Where would you cut costs?" To this challenge the National Economy League has replied with a concrete plan for a balanced budget in the fiscal year beginning next July.

When the National Association of Manufacturers meets in the Waldorf-Astoria tonight to honor the nation's foremost living inventors and research workers, one of the guests will be Mr. Henry Abbott.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Secretary Morgenthau declared today at his press conference that "I have never been interpreted in any matter by so many people" as in regard to the appointment of a trustee in the case of the bankrupt Associated Gas and Electric System. He added that many of the interpretations were wrong.

Former Magistrate Alexander Brough is ill at his home, 31 West Twelfth Street. Mrs. Brough said last night that her husband is "desperately ill with a very severe attack of pneumonia." His condition, she added, was so serious that it was impossible to remove him to a hospital.

Two thousand members of the Seventy-eighth Division of the A.E. F. are expected to attend a reunion meeting on Saturday, April 20, at the Hotel Capitol, Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue, it was announced yesterday. The meeting has been arranged by the Seventyeighth Division Veterans Association, of which E. Jerry Kamen of Newark, N.J., is president.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 26 (AP) --Leading Article, winner of the 1938 Inaugural Handicap at Oaklawn Park, repeated his performance at the opening of the 1940 season today. Sweeping Tide was second and Tack Point third.

The second in the series of Yorkville dinner dances for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association will be held on April 2 in the ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Joseph P. Dixon heads the senior committee for the event. Mrs. McClure Meredith Howland, who is chairman of the junior committee, will give a tea today at the Plaza in the interests of the dinner dance.

TOKYO, Feb. 26--That Japan's military and economic activities in China will continue on a large scale and the Japanese people must tighten their belts for an indefinite time is the substance of the army's reply to recent outcries about scarcity.

BERGEN, Norway, Feb. 26--Norwegian whaling companies have now concluded the season's cam paign in the Antarctic with results above the average. Today a large deal was concluded with Britain, which bought a couple of hundred thousand tons at 37.10s per ton.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP)--The La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L.I., accepted an invitation tonight to participate in the twenty-first annual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament March 28-30. La Salle, winner of eighteen straight games, joins Seton Hall Prep of South Orange, N.J., defending champions; Salem (Mass.) High School and Durham (N.C.) High School.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Argentina's export trade with the United States during January showed an increase of 79 per cent over last year, according to the American consulate-general in Buenos Aires.

Mrs. Ada C. Blodget, widow of Henry Townsend Blodget, architect, and active in civic, religious and educational affairs here and in New Rochelle, N.Y., died here yesterday at her home, 90 Barrow Street. She would have been 71 years old March 12.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 26--While investigating the high relief costs of New Rochelle, city officials learned today that one family on relief for the last four years had bought a Summer home at Brentwood, L.I., in 1937 and had interrupted its annual vacations there long enough to return to this city once a week to collect its checks for food, clothing and shelter.
PINE CAMP, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP) --White-shrouded soldiers skied through their first Winter "battle" today but the only casualties were newspaper photographers sent to cover the event.
LONDON, Feb. 26--Suggestions from Copenhagen, Denmark, that the Scandinavian countries might be prepared to mediate the RussoFinnish conflict were received here today with reserved interest.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 28 (AP)-- Pat Fehley, halfback from Easton, Pa., and Howell Stroupe, center from Cherryville, were elected cocaptains of the 1940 North Carolina State football team today. ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26 (UP)--The legislative commission of the National Education Association tonight assailed President Roosevelt's educational policies and declared that his "inaction" in the field of public education "is a matter of disappointment to every one interested in the work of the public schools and in our democracy."

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Feb. 26 (AP)--Anti-aircraft batteries opened fire and searchlights swept the skies in Amersfort and surrounding villages tonight. Residents reported that planes believed to be of a foreign nationality had passed over the section at high altitude.

A large reception committee will greet subscribers to the "Dixie Dinner Dance" tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. The reception, which will precede the dinner, will be held in the east foyer of the hotel.

PARIS, Feb. 26 (AP)--Archduke Otto, Habsburg claimant to the nonexistent throne of Austria, obtained a visa from the United States Embassy today and is expected to fly from Lisbon, Portugal, to the United States this week.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 27--The Air Ministry announced today that the Royal Air Force had made reconnaissance flights over Helgoland and had also penetrated as far as Berlin in the last twenty-four hours.

Prominent Scandinavians living in New York are among the patrons of the first annual Book Fair and luncheon to be held next Monday in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--The Senate adopted tonight a resolution introduced by Senator John J. McNaboe, Democrat, Manhattan, memorializing Congress to pass legislation barring any President of the United States from obtaining a third-term nomination.
The two-family frame house at 192 Monroe Street, Brooklyn, was leased by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Elizabeth MeKenna through the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers in the deal.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26--The election of Communist party officials, which has been going on the last two weeks, will continue for two weeks more throughout Russia.
Automobile production advanced last week when the seasonal trend was unchanged, and the adjusted index advanced to 112.8 from 104.4. It was 87.4 for the week ended Feb. 25, 1939.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26--An invader from New Orleans took some of the best sprinters into camp today as the final week of the Hialeah forty-six-day session began. W.F. Mannagh's Liberty Flight, who won a handicap at the Crescent City's Fair Grounds track by four lengths prior to shipping here, surprised the betting fraternity.

Bids for 1,000 steel box cars to be bought by the New York Central Railroad will be opened on March 13. The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad has ordered fifty covered hopper cars from the American Car and Foundry Company. The United States Engineers Department has ordered twenty-four box cars from the Greenville Steel Car Company.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 26-- One of the notable feats credited to the fort at Koivisto, reported here today to have fallen to the Russian invaders, was the putting out of action of the 23,000-ton Soviet battleship October Revolution.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28--Nearly 20,000 job-seekers, some of whom had been shivering in the chill blasts of the meadowlands here since 1 A.M., besieged the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation at Newark airport this morning.
Commercial and industrial failures in the five-day week ended Feb. 22 numbered 225, compared with 292 in the preceding week and 267 in the 1939 week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--De Paul's basketball team tonight put on its best show of the year by beating the famed Long Island University five, 44 to 36, in the Coliseum.

The University of Toronto rang up its seventh straight victory to be assured of at least a tie for the International Division title; Toronto's Don Dunbar, who has been leading the individual scoring race most of the season, virtually clinched the honors by adding four points to his total, and Princeton's parade to the Quadrangular League crown was interrupted by Yale.

BERLIN, Feb. 26--The journey of Summer Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State to Berlin, continues to be the sole topic of speculation in neutral diplomatic quarters and if the German Foreign Office is in possession of any information touching on the exact nature of his mission the secret is being rigidly guarded.

A copy of the French imperial edition of the Old Testament, with illustrations by Tissot, was presented to the Brooklyn Public Library yesterday by the Brooklyn Civic Council in appreciation of the library's services to the community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Italy, which has little coal, is experimenting with gasoline driven trains, according to Assistant American Commercial Attache Malcolm P. Hooper in Rome. Three such trains equipped with two 1,400horsepower motors are now being tested by the State Railways. A test journey between Genoa and Milan, a distance of ninety-three and three-fourths miles, was made in 1 hour 30 minutes at an average hourly speed of 65 miles.

Corper, research director of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, which is celebrating the completion of forty years of nonsectarian service to America's tubercular poor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (UP)--John M. Pratt, executive administrator of the national physicians committee for the extension of medical service, denied today that the committee was conducting a lobby for the American Medical Association.

Traffic officials met in the Trunk Line Association's office at 143 Liberty Street yesterday to prepare tariffs in conformity with the Interstate Commerce Commission's order for a 2-cent coach rate in the East and adjourned without announcement.

Weakness in many minor items caused the Annalist index of commodity prices to decline sharply last week. On Saturday the index was 81.4 per cent of the 1926 base, the lowest since early in December and a drop of 0.4 point, compared with the preceding week.

The New York Curb Exchange removed yesterday $100 par 6 per cent preferred stock of International Products Corporation from listing, in accordance with permission granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the Exchange's application to strike the issue from listing and registration.

Varsity baseball practice opened at Fordham yesterday. Twenty-five candidates reported to Coach Jack Coffey and participated in a light workout in the gymnasium. Indoor practice will continue daily until weather conditions permit work outdoors. The Rams will launch a difficult 21-game schedule against St. Peter's on March 30.

The Swedish Parliament's action, in restricting rigidly the export of gold, drafts or bank notes, is obviously a protective measure. Its primary purpose is the conservation of Sweden's gold. The ordinance, indeed, is in this respect not as sweeping as our own "Gold Reserve Act" of 1934, and no change in the New York exchange rate on Sweden has followed it.

Hopper Home of 110 Second Avenue disclosed yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26 (UP)-- The B.F. Goodrich Company of Akron, Ohio, has obtained permission to establish a tire-manufacturing plant in Chile, it was learned tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26 (UP)--Twelve Croat separatists were arrested today at Zagreb after some small bombs had exploded at a number of points in the city's center without causing material damage or injuries. Those arrested included the well-known Croat leaders, Dr. Milan Buc and Dr. Milan Butak.

Mayor La Guardia issued yesterday a call for the Brooklyn members of the City Council to meet at 4 o'clock on Monday in the Appellate Division Court House, Brooklyn, to select a successor to the late Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll.

The Holland-America liner Noordam arrived at Fifth Street, Hoboken, N.J., yesterday from Rotterdam with forty-five passengers, $2,000,000, 5,000 canaries and 120 white swans that are being imported for resale to large estates in this country.

Four girl students of the Our Lady of Perpetual Help Parochial School were bitten slightly yesterday afternoon by a small white Spitz dog that ran into the school playground at Sixtieth Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn. The victims were treated by an ambulance surgeon from Norwegian Hospital and sent to their homes.
Lee Savold, Des Moines heavyweight, and Bob Pastor, whom he will meet in a twelve-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, went through rigorous workouts yesterday.

A jury of one woman and thirteen men from a blue-ribbon panel of talesmen, with two of the men alternates, was chosen speedily yesterday in General Sessions for the trial of Ellwood M. Rabenold, former Democratic State Senator and lawyer, in alleged frauds of about $1,000,000 in loans to the Garcia Sugars Corporation since 1901.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 27 (UP)-- James R. Young, Tokyo manager for the International News Service, who was arrested Jan. 21, has been indicted on charges of violating the Japanese Army penal code, it was announced today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26-- The Paramount Theatre was filled to capacity tonight for the concert by the National Symphony Orchestra, of which Dr. Hans Kindler is conductor and at which Miss Florence Hartley, soprano and former scholarship pupil of Mme. Louise Homer, was soloist.

LONDON, Feb. 26--An urn containing the ashes of Lord Tweedsmuir arrived today on the British warship that brought it from Canada. A naval guard of honor was mounted and at the quayside were two of the Governor General's sons and the High Commissioner of Canada, Vincent Massey.
The Columbian National Life Insurance Company of Boston reports assets of $48,138,785 at the close of 1939, a high record and a gain of $1,922,116 for the year.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 26 (UP) --George McClelland Reynolds, former chairman of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, Chicago, and a leading national financier, died tonight after a long illness. His age was 75. He had been living here several years with his son, Earle Reynolds.

The collection for the Finnish Relief Fund taken up at the national A.A.U. track and field championships last Saturday amounted to $1,067. This is approximately twice the sum raised in a previous effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The British and French Governments have available sufficient dollars not only to pay for the airplanes and engines now on order in this country but also for the contemplated $1,000,000,000 Allied purchasing program, Secretary Morgenthau stated at his press conference this afternoon.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 26-- Metropolitan stars were among the winning combinations today in the first round of match play of the annual Miami-Biltmore amateur four-ball golf tournament.

A suit to restrain Alex Rose, as secretary, and Luigi Antonini, as State chairman of the American Labor party, from severing the affiliations of four district clubs with the party was filed yesterday in Supreme Court. Bertrand Russell, noted British philosopher, was appointed Professor of Philosophy at City College last night by the Board of Higher Education, meeting at the college, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. Albert Delavigne, president of Roure-Dupont Co., dealers in essential oils, has leased an apartment of ten rooms and four baths in the building at 983 Park Avenue through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, managing owners, and Chace Chace, brokers.

New bond financing this week aggregated $133,310,000, the largest for any similar period in more than six and one-half months, or since the week ended Aug. 11, 1939, when $165,240,000 in new bonds were placed on the market.

R. L. Gerry of the home club reached the semi-final round of the national amateur court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club when he defeated his club-mate, C. F. Havemeyer, 6-1, 6-3, 6-3.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 1--Returning from his two-day scouting expedition in Miami to greet his second squad today, Colonel Bill Terry got his first glimpse of two young men who in the weeks to come are likely to play an important role in shaping the 1940 fortunes of the Giants.

WASHINGTON, March 1--In a ceremony unprecedented so far as the annals of the Supreme Court go, a father, mother and son, William H. Faust, Mrs. William H. Faust and William H. Faust Jr. of Indianapolis were today admitted simultaneously to practice before the high court.

A new building will be added to the cluster of structures used for film storage and exchanges in the vicinity of Ninth Avenue and Fortyfourth Street, it was learned yesterday, when plans were filed for a six-story building at 332 to 346 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Roundlot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 10 was 4,090,630 shares, compared with 3,204,745 shares in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Under a combination of foreign and domestic selling, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined 11 to 16 points yesterday and ended at the low point of the day.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 1--Louis Napoleon Ellrodt, last of the city Republican leaders in Westchester County under the late William L. Ward, who was county chairman for thirty-seven years, died suddenly of a heart attack today in his home here at the age of 57. He was vice president of the National Electrotype Corporation, 227 East Forty-fifth Street, New York, with which he had been connected for fifteen years.

LONDON, March 1--In one of the most extensive reconnoitering expeditions since the war began, an undetermined number of Royal Air Force planes made bombless flights early this morning over German territory.

Herr von Ribbentrop is reported to have told Mr. Sumner Welles yesterday that Germany is not prepared to consider peace unless and until Great Britain's "stranglehold on the economic life of the world" is broken. Of what does this "stranglehold" consist?

COLUMBIA, Mo., March 1--Urging that each State provide for a system of junior colleges attached to cosmopolitan high schools, Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, addressed tonight the annual meet ing of the American Association of Junior Colleges, whose first meeting he called in St. Louis twenty years ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 (AP)-- Water still poured through broken dikes tonight and hundreds of thousands of acres of rich farm lands remained submerged, but the crisis appeared passed in Northern California's devastating flood.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 1--Because 75 per cent of its 106 employes are of Finnish or Scandinavian ancestory, the Mount Vernon Die Casting Corporation of 118 Pearl Street, this city, rejected today a contract to make dies and parts for Russian tanks, automobiles and tractors.
WASHINGTON, March 1--Senator Reynolds, Democrat of North Carolina, went into a Senate subcommittee meeting today with a grievance and came out with a race horse.

Proposals for complete abolition of the department of stock list of the New York Stock Exchange have reached the point of serious discussion in inner circles of that institution. Proponents would throw the market open to trading in any registered issue, on the pattern of the London Stock Exchange.

With substantial advances in three classifications, advertising linage in eight New York newspapers for February advanced 3.6 per cent over the like month of last year, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Linage for last month totaled 7,098,958, as against 6,849,174 in January of 1939.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)-- Six Democratic Senators joined today in an open revolt against efforts by Secretary Wallace to revamp the government's farm credit facilities.

SHANGHAI, March 1--The International Settlement has won little in today's agreement with the Japanese permitting Settlement police to return to a small part of the Settlement area north of Soochow Creek.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT TO WASHINGTON, March 1--The fifteen-day vacation cruise that took him over 4,000 miles of open sea and included an intensive inspection of Panama Canal defenses was ended by President Roosevelt today in a "peasoup" fog that hung over the naval base at Pensacola, Fla., and delayed his debarkation by several hours.

PITTSBURGH, March 1 (AP)-- Third Baseman Lee Handley signed a contract for the 1940 season with the Pirates today at the San Bernardino, Calif., training camp, President William E. Benswanger informed headquarters here. Only Pitcher Russell Bauers and Shortstop Arky Vaughan are out of the fold.
Officials of the New York Stock Exchange have been working for the last three weeks to obtain the listing of the forthcoming New York City transit unification bonds.
For the first time in New York City school history, the Board of Education has appealed to Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, to revoke the license of a high school teacher.

After deliberating thirteen hours and thirty-nine minutes, a jury in General Sessions found Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Max Silverman and the latter's son, Harold, guilty of extortion in the bakery and trucking racket at 1:24 A. M. today.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell, who is supervising the reorganization proceedings of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, top holding company of the $1,000,000,000 utilities system, and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, named yesterday three trustees for the organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1-The National Labor Relations Board, in a decision made public here today, held the Federation of Baldwin Employes to be a company-dominated union and ordered the Baldwin Locomotive Works in Easton, Pa., to "cease and desist" from any further connection with it.

The $1,000,000 promised by American industry to the Finnish Relief Fund has been more than half subscribed with the raising of $600,000 so far, Frederick W. Gehle, vice president of the Chase National Bank of New York, announced last night.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1--Manager Joe McCarthy opened class for the Yankees today on a new topic, the amended pitching rules, and closed it with most of his pitchers, regulars and rookies, deep in confusion.

The Rev. Frederick A. Bowers, pastor since 1921 of St. John's Lutheran Church, 114th Street and Jamaica Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, died yesterday at his home, 85-65 114th Street, Richmond Hill, after a heart attack following an illness of several months. He was 76 years old.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 1-- Judge Patrick J. Ryan, founder and dean of the Municipal Court since its creation in 1893; died last night in St. Joseph Hospital at the age of 79. He suffered a stroke yesterday morning.

PARIS, March 1--The elaborate preparations being made here to give Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State, a cordial and appropriate reception are being somewhat hampered by the fact that the French Government is unable to obtain any accurate information as to when he will arrive.

LONDON, March 1--How Premier Mussolini will react when the British begin interfering with Italy's sea-borne coal imports from Germany after today provides one of the most interesting diplomatic riddles of the week.

James Morgan Hutton Sr., senior partner of the firm of W. E. Hutton Co., investment bankers, died suddenly at 4:10 o'clock. yesterday afternoon of heart disease in the firm's offices at 14 Wall Street. He had celebrated his seventieth birthday on Feb. 21.

The eight-story apartment house at 514 West 114th Street, near Columbia University, has been sold by Samuel Reznick to the Pethan Corporation for investment. Accommodating thirty-two families in suites of five and seven rooms, the buildinx is on a plot 75 by 101 feet.

WASHINGTON, March 1-Attorney General Jackson absolved today the Federal Bureau of Investigation of misconduct or unwarranted exercise of authority in its arrest of sixteen persons at Detroit on charges of recruiting for the Spanish Loyalist Army.

WASHINGTON, March 1--To Lieutenant Harold L. Neely of the Army Air Corps has been awarded the Cheney Award for the outstanding act of valor by a member last year.

Leaders in the fields of religion, education and the arts joined yesterday with officers and representatives of various women's organizations in discussing social problems confronting the nation at an interfaith symposium in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of eight of these organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 1--A total of 108 supply contracts, valued at $3,640,165, was awarded during the week ended Feb. 24 by eleven Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Net income of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for 1939 was $8,802,811 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $7,412,072 in 1938, an increase of $670,739, or 9 per cent, according to the twentieth annual report, made public yesterday by David Sarnoff, president.

Plans for a country residence were announced in connection with the purchase by William Schmidt of six acres adjoining the estate of W. Thorn Kissel at Bedminster, N. J. The land was sold by Mrs. Arabella Tiger through the Wilmer N. Tuttle Agency.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. McCullough of New York will entertain tomorrow night at the "Great Guns" gala dinner dance at the Surf Club for Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lafayette Jones of New York, their house guests at the McCullough residence in Surfside.

PATNA, India, March 1--Growing temper in the Indian Congress party was voiced today in a strongly worded resolution dissociating the party from the war and holding out the threat of a civil disobedience campaign as the next step toward complete Indian independence.

ROME, March 1--The end of the Fascist Militia as an independent fighting unit took place today when 132 battalions of militiamen were officially incorporated in the Italian Army with solemn ceremonies held in many Italian cities.
With all the tournaments that have been in progress, the past week has emphasized again the growing popularity of court games--squash, badminton and court tennis. In origin these are all old-timers.

Declinations were filed with the Board of Elections last night by seven designees for delegates to the Democratic National Convention and six alternates, all pledged to the cause of Vice President Garner.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Arguing that a divorcee has an inalienable right to keep her past marital difficulties a secret, Senator Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, continued his fight today on questions to be included in the 1940 census.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)-- The American Federation of Labor, announcing tonight the start of its "greatest organizing drive in the South," predicted that by the end of the year it would have 500,000 new members in ten Southern States.

The American Association for Cancer Research comprises about four hundred scientists who have devoted their lives to the study of normal and abnormal growths. It is a loose organization without legal status.

The Metropolitan Opera Fund's campaign for $1,000,000 to buy the historic Broadway house and widen the base of interest in opera, passed the $500,000 mark yesterday, George A. Sloan, chairman of the campaign committee, announced.

ALBANY, March 7--Extension of the State Unemployment Insurance Law to include coverage of parttime workers in benefit payments was recommended today in the final report of the special committee of the State Labor Department which has been investigating the question for three years.

With the arrival of the Queen Elizabeth yesterday it was announced that the special police detail now protecting the Hudson River waterfront has been augmented until it now numbers 157 men, who are being maintained at a cost of more than $1,300 a day.

LONDON, March 7--Sir Kingsley Wood, the Air Minister, told the House of Commons today that Allied production of war planes was now greater than Germany's output. He warned the Nazis that, if they seriously attacked this country "our bomber force will be both ready and able to hit hard, hit often and keep on hitting."
A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of $2,500,000 City of Yonkers, N.Y., bonds on a bid of 100.02 for a combination of 3s and 3 s.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., March 7 (AP)--Dr. Frank Butler Trotter, former president of West Virginia University, died here today at the age of 77.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 7 --F.J. Buchanan's Charlieinfeld, 3to-10 favorite, took the featured Palm Beach Purse at Tropical Park today after the stewards disqualified W.H. (Bill) Gallagher's Wise Bee, who was first across the finish line.

International trends in 1940 fashions continued to emerge yesterday as salient features of the Spring mode in four more seasonal showings at New York institutions. Interest pivoted between the French importations and the American adaptations. Selections from the dominant designers underscored among the day's developments the "mermaid silhouette," the prevalence of stripes, the importance of amber yellow in accessories, and a whole species of new fabrics.

Two superb compositions, Schubert's "Tragic" symphony and Mozart's "Coronation" piano concerto, formed the backbone of last night's program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, at Carnegie Hall.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 7--President Roberto M. Ortiz intervened in the Province of Buenos Aires today and appointed General Luis Casinelli Federal Interventor to replace Governor Manuel Fresco pending new elections.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Colonel Frederic L. Huidekoper, military writer and World War veteran, died this morning in Emergency Hospital of injuries suffered last Sunday night when he was struck by a street car. He was 66 years old.

Students at the High School of Music and Art have voted "consideration for others" the most important trait they like to find in their classmates, it was reported yesterday. In all, ten characteristics were listed as being important to make a student popular.

An egg surplus is piling up rapidly here and prices were reduced again this week, to 35 cents a dozen for Grade A whites and 26 cents for mixed Grade B's. Next week several organizations in the egg trade plan a publicity campaign to increase consumption of eggs.

Debussy's lonely and incomparable opera, "Pelleas et Melisande," was brought back to the Metropolitan reportory last night after an absence therefrom of five years. This could be called Edward Johnson's concluding revival of the season, and he richly deserves the thanks of his public for it.

The continued struggle of monthly magazines to beat last year's figures is an excellent example of advertisers' desire for flexibility in media, agency men pointed out yesterday.

Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C., seeded third, was among the favorites to win yesterday in the opening round of the national squash tennis championship at the Princeton Club. Lordi defeated A.M. Moody, Yale Club, 15--5, 15--3, 15--5.

LONDON, March 7--Joseph P. Boston's mighty Bruins, holders of the world hockey championship, moved into first place in the National Hockey League race by defeating the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, 2 to 1.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7-- More than a thousand couples will dance at the annual Yale Junior Promenade, which will be held tomorrow night in the Payne Whitney gymnasium, which was chosen this year instead of the Woolsey Hall Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)--The Federal Power Commission was told today by Victor G. Gouch, one of its examiners, that operating affiliates of the Associated Gas and Electric System in Pennsylvania paid "hundreds of thousands of dollars" for services never rendered in their behalf.

Talk of peace in the Russo-Finnish war was received with mixed reactions in Europe's capitals yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8-- Michelle Morgan, French film actress who was seen in this country recently in "Port of Shadows," is negotiating a term contract with RKO under which the star will come to Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, March 10--Perhaps the most far-reaching surprise of the European war has been the widespread use by the Germans of self-sealing, puncture-proof airplane fuel tanks. President Roosevelt for a third term he wonders whether the President, if he won re-election, would regard it as a mandate and perhaps institute radical changes in our foreign policy as a result.

Plans were completed last night for the formal opening at 2 P.M. today of the twenty seventh annual international flower show in Grand Central Palace. Conducted under the joint auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists Club, the exhibition will remain open to the public for six days. After the opening today, the show will be open from 10 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.

PITTSBURGH, March 10--Conditions apparent in the steel industry last week again presented specific evidence of the quietness in steel markets, the continuation of the leveling-off process in new business and the uninterrupted downward adjustment in ingot output rate.

An entirely new exhibit to be called Gas Wonderland will be spon sored at the World's Fair by the Gas yesterday of America, which became yesterday the first 1939 exhibitor to announce such extensive plans for a complete overhauling and revision of its last season's exhibit.

James Russell Osterman, 28 years old, of 224 East Eighty-sixth Street, who was arrested Saturday night on suspicion of fatally stabbing a shoe store proprietor, was held without bail yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Anna M. Kross for a hearing in Homicide Court tomorrow.

AMSTERDAM, March 9--After the firm tendency of belligerent markets in the preceding week, last week--again with the exception of Berlin--showed a tone of general reserve and indecision on both neutral and belligerent Bourses.

The National Maritime Union, which has been planning ever since last July to launch a drive to unite all American unlicensed seamen, announced yesterday that it was sending a field organizer to the West Coast this week as an initial step toward national unity.

An exhibition of 350 rare English books and manuscripts ranging from the sixteenth century to the present was opened privately yesterday afternoon at Edgar H. Wells Co., 602 Madison Avenue, and will be on view to the public starting today.
