Kaup, Vicar-General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Richmond and rector of the Sacred Heart Cathedral here, died this morning in JohnstonWillis Hospital after a brief illness. He was 60 years old. He was a leader in the campaign for clean films.

BRENNERO, Italy, March 18--In the beflagged station of this Italian Alpine village, which formerly belonged to Austria, Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler this morning held a two-and-a-halfhours' conversation aboard Signor...

Harold E. Dahl and his wife, reunited since Sunday after being kept apart for several years by the war in Spain and its aftermath, faced reporters and photographers together yesterday and called rumors that they would separate "false and unfounded."

The report for 1939 of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $33,947,443 after taxes, depreciation and retirements, but before mine depletion, equal to $3.14 each on the 10,821,653 capital shares.

Mayor La Guardia, laying the cornerstone for Vladeck City Houses yesterday, declared that he would let the beneficial results of his public housing program serve as an answer to those who criticized the program.

Parisian trends of 1940, in their American translations, reached the runway yesterday afternoon at Gimbel's in a collection of "cablenews" costumes emphasizing the salient features of the Spring mode.

LONDON, March 18--Uncertainty as to the implications of the HitlerMussolini meeting and the first day's operation of the new minima for government funds emphasized the general nervousness in the stock markets today.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 18 (AP)--The Indians found the Phillies easy pickings today and achieved an 11-4 exhibition triumph which cost them the services of Shortstop Lou Boudreau for at least two weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18--Dr. William Gibson Spiller, widely known neurologist, teacher and writer on medical subjects, died tonight in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital after a long illness. His age was 76.

Attorney General Jackson's order to the Federal Bureau of Investigation to discontinue "wire-tapping, entrapment or the use of any other improper, illegal or unethical tactics in procuring information" brings the FBI into conformity with the position taken by the Supreme Court.

Cracksmen baffled neither by a steel-barred window nor by massive safes stole watches valued at from $10,000 to $20,000 sometime Sunday night from the wholesale silver, glass and jewelry loft of the A. Cohen Sons Corporation, just off Fifth Avenue at 27 West Twentythird Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Tuesday, March 19--Pari-mutuel betting at New Jersey race tracks became a reality this morning when the State Legislature, reconvening after midnight, confirmed early this morning the nomination by Governor A. Harry Moore of two Democrats and two Republicans to constitute the State Racing Commission.

HAVING at least a rudimentary conscience, I laid-plans. But the hazards of travel are great, and the best of plans will sometimes fail. For Monday it would be Professor Weber's "Hardy of Wessex." For Tuesday--well, whatever proved available was to be shipped south to Barrios on the S.S. Iriona, and the returning passenger was to lie on the sundeck and dutifully read.
Although the regular season of the National Hockey League is over, competition in the ice sport begins in earnest tonight.

Mrs. Wales Latham, chairman of the junior committee for the Yorkville Dinner Dance to be held on April 2 at the Plaza for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association, gave a tea yesterday at the hotel for Mrs. Cruger G. Fowler, vice chairman, and members of the committee.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 18-- Professor Casey Stengel's Bees, who at first do not impress one as an outfit that is apt to go far this year, went far enough today to exagerate Colonel Bill Terry.
If the Nobel Prize committee happens to be sitting we think we have something. We discovered yesterday that Spring fever is highly contagious.

In an ardent plea to save the "right of decent living and of individual liberty" in Europe, Count Jerzy Potocki, Polish Ambassador to the United States, described the condition of his countrymen last night as "the most ter rible in history."

LONDON, March 18--The belligerents have come to a turning point. That is the unquestioned belief in informed circles here tonight. Nobody knows whether Chancellor Hitler, in his conversation with Premier Mussolini today, asked his...

The amateur boxing team representing Chicago rallied after a faltering start to earn a tie with the squad wearing the colors of New York City in the Golden Gloves intercity tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.
Plans have been completed for the observation of Conservation Day, New Jersey's official celebration of Wildlife Restoration Week, which will be held on Saturday at the Stacy-Trent Hotel in Trenton.

An eleven-room apartment in the multi-family building at 1,035 Fifth Avenue has been leased to Laszlo Medgyesy, Hungarian Consul General, who recently was transferred to this city from Chicago, it was announced yesterday by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers in the transaction.

KANSAS CITY, March 18--Walter Mehl, former Wisconsin runner, defeated Taisto Maki of Finland tonight in a special two-mile race that featured the Missouri Valley A.A.U. track meet. Mehl won by a stride, with Glenn Cunningham of Kansas ten yards back.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)-- An attorney for the Federal Power Commission charged today that employes of the Associated Gas and Electric System who invested their savings in bonds and notes of an affiliated investing company "never got it out."

TAMPA, Fla., March 18--The talk of the town is of the big baseball gathering for fun and the Finns. Everybody had a great time. Lefty Gomez of the Yankees encountered Big Mose Grove of the Red Sox, who recently celebrated his fortieth birthday.

WASHINGTON, March 18--In carrying to conclusion one of its most important proceedings under the Holding Company Act to date, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed today an application in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York requesting affirmation and enforcement of a plan of reorganization for the Community Power and Light Company.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)-- Proponents of a $212,000,000 appro priation for farm-parity payments told the Senate today that the sum could be voted without levying new taxes and without increasing the statutory debt limit.

PARIS, March 18--Malcolm MacDonald, British Colonial Secretary, concluded his colonial talks with the French Minister of Colonies, Georges Mandel, and returned to London tonight but details of the plans for Franco-British colonial cooperation will be worked out by experts who will meet shortly for the purpose.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., March 18 --Bartenders at the Bucket of Blood Saloon, the Crystal Bar and other allied enterprises of this ghost town estimated last night that they had sold nearly $50,000 worth of refreshments to 20,000 people who came here for the silver lode country's first movie premiere.

TOKYO, March 18--Japan and Argentina have agreed to fix their mutual trade at 30,000,000 yen each annually, an increase of 33 per cent over last year's business, but 35 per cent under the pre-China war figures. [The yen is quoted at 23.43 cents.]

BALTIMORE, March 18--A hundred years of progress in United States dentistry was described today to more than 2,000 dentists and their guests at the opening sessions of the dental centenary celebration.

At a time when many other museums at a bewailing their financial difficulties, the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, has been able to wipe out its debt, it was disclosed yesterday in the institution's annual report.
A great deal more is being said in Berlin than in Rome about the results of yesterday's rendezvous in the Alps.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Upward minimum wage adjustments affecting about 24,500 of the 83,000 employes in the knitted underwear and knitted outerwear industries were approved today by Colonel Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division of the Department of Labor.

An overflow crowd that included many high-ranking army and navy officials attended funeral services in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street, yesterday for Colonel George W. Burleigh, lawyer, soldier, civic leader and churchman.

The St. Francis Prep quintet defeated Brooklyn Prep, 34--29, in the final of the eleventh annual metropolitan Catholic high school invitation basketball tournament at the Columbus Club in Brooklyn last night before a crowd of 1,800. The rivals were tied at half-time, 13--13.
The busy Times Square district is about to lose one of its earliest landmarks.

Henry Hill Pierce of 9 East Ninety-fourth Street, who was a member of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell from 1909 until his retirement in 1929, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a week's illness at the age of 64.
Some observers in this country and in England have been critical over the role played by Sweden during the invasion of Finland.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18-- Pierre L. Barbey Jr. was a dinner host tonight at his oceanfront home to a company including Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Jacob L. Webb, Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor,...
Easter shopping gathered momentum in local department stores and specialty shops yesterday, with executives estimating sales increases of 10 per cent or more over a year ago.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 18-- The professional golfers have come back to Pinehurst to play the $4,000 North and South open championship for the thirty-eighth year, and the defending champion is Byron Nelson, who won this aged event in 1939 with a score of 283, then went on to tie for the national open at Philadelphia in a similar figure and win the play-off from Craig Wood and Denny Shute.

ALBANY, March 18--The question of imposing tolls on the State Barge Canal was debated here today for more than four hours before the Assembly Judiciary Committee at a hearing on a proposed constitutional amendment permitting the Legislature to levy canal tolls.

ALBANY, March 18--Without debate and by a unanimous vote the Senate passed tonight and sent to the Assembly another Republican budget proposal, the Hampton bill, giving the State the unclaimed funds held by domestic life insurance companies.

Following are the principal sections of the suanmary of the 65page letter sent yesterday to Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, by E.F. Connely, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America:

Championship dates of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, as tentatively scheduled by the executive committee, were submitted yesterday afternoon to delegates of the many clubs of the association who will meet March 29 in the New York Yacht Club.
Garner candidates for posts as delegates to the Democratic National Convention made a clean sweep of first places yesterday in the drawing far ballot positions in the April 2 Spring primary.
Proposed changes in the pension plan of the Texas Corporation will be submitted to shareholders at the annual meeting to be held in this city on April 23.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 18 (AP)--Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N.C., set the pace today in the first round of the annual mid-South women's medal play golf tournament with 36, 40-- 76, which gave her a seven-stroke lead.

LONDON, March 18--Lieut. Gen. Sir Aylmer Hunter-Weston, whose military career was marked by reckless courage and wide technical knowledge, was killed by a fall from the turret of his house at West Kilbride, Ayrshire, today. He was 75 years old.

With the opening of the New York racing season set for Monday, April 15, at Jamaica, dates for the seven stake events during the twenty-fourday meeting were announced yesterday by Dr. Edward P. Kilroe, president of the Metropolitan Jockey Club which operates the track.

A banking group comprising the First Boston Corporation, Bankamerica Company and Whiting, Weeks Stubbs, Inc., the high bidder for an issue of $750,000 of City and County of Honolulu, Hawaii, 3 per cent sewer bonds, formally reoffered the bonds yesterday at prices to yield 1.25 to 2.40 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Local participation in a proposed hospital program involving Federal expenditures of $10,000,000 in its first year of operation was requested today by the American Medical Association, in testimony by spokesmen before a Senate Labor subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, March 18--The Senate overwhelmingly adopted today the Hatch bill to control political activities among State jobholders paid in whole or in part with Federal funds.
The latest German air raid on Scapa Flow was successful enough to have caused complaints in England, for the first time in this war, about the "leisurely" work of the defending fighter squadrons.

Echoes of pre-depression days in the Manhattan realty market, when builders and operators were feverishly assembling or buying up available sites for new apartment buildings in various parts of the borough, were heard yesterday when it was learned that the property at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-second Street had been acquired by a builder for the erection of a six-story apartment house.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 18-- About a quarter of a century ago the golden Russian aristocracy enjoyed the Summer vacation around Hangoe's white casino, where the Summer is milder and more attractive than anywhere else in Finland.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Elimination of static, discrimination and exclusion of unwanted sound were the major superiorities of frequency over amplitude modulation, it was asserted today by Major Edwin H. Armstrong of New York City, inventor of frequency modulation; at the opening hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.

There was a world premiere, a first New York performance and an impressive feat of versatility and endurance at Carnegie Hall last night when the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, gave its fifth evening concert.

Latin-American countries must have dollar exchange to continue their buying from manufacturers in this country, Edward J. Noble, Under-Secretary of Commerce, told the monthly meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night.
LONDON, March 18 (AP)--A calm defense of his national government against rebellious criticism in the House of Commons was prepared tonight by Prime Minister Chamberlain.

Joseph Stalin will receive American royalties on a collection of excerpts from his writings published today by Howell, Soskin Co. under the title "Stalin's Kampf," the publishing house announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 18--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 13: Increases of $12,000,000...

WASHINGTON, March 18--Every old-age pension claimant is now entitled to a hearing and review if he or she questions the amount of the award, according to an announcement today by the Social Security Board, which stated that the board...
Harry Sophus Sheldon, an immigrant Danish boy who became a success as a Broadway playwright in the years before the World War, was found dead yesterday of gas poisoning, apparently a suicide.

The door to a peaceful settlement of the controversy between Mayor La Guardia and the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, over the post-unification statue of 27,000 employes of the Interborough and B.M.T. transit systems remained open yesterday after the Mayor had conferred at City Hall more than an hour with a union delegation headed by John L. Lewis, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A program calling for retailing liquor under their own label has been worked out by 190 package stores in the Long Island Wine and Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., Abe Shapiro, president of the organization, said last night.

CHICAGO, March 18--Speculation as to, whether the conference between Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler forecasts a peace or a new war drive in Europe dominated the course or activities in the grain markets today.

Entering Into the 1940 World's Fair campaign to present New York as a place the tourist may visit cheaply, the Merchants Association of New York turned yesterday to last year's record to explode "wild stories" about high prices.
George Dietrich testified in Federal court yesterday that "the higher-ups" knew all about the $21,000,000 inflation of the assets of McKesson Robbins, Inc., of which he was assistant treasurer.

It is Walter Huston who will have the leading role of the new William Saroyan play, "Love's Old Sweet Song," which is now in rehearsal. Before yesterday, when Mr. Huston signed a contract to appear in the play, Henry Hull had been rehearsing the part--a role he found unsuitable and from which he withdrew.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18--The defeat by the National League in the citrus belt All-Star game may have been a blow to the American League, but the contest proved highly gratifying to the Yankees generally and to Marse Joe McCarthy in particular.

RAMGARH, India, March 18-- The subjects committee of the AllIndia Nationalist Congress today adopted a resolution reiterating the Congress's demand for the complete independence of India and declaring Indian freedom could not exist "within the orbit of British imperialism."

A merger plan linking CurtissWright Corporation, one of the nation's leading aircraft manufacturing concerns, and Atlas Corporation, perhaps the best known investment company in the United States, was agreed upon in principle by the heads of the two companies yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18-- Gary Cooper was borrowed today from Samuel Goldwyn by the Frank Capra-Robert Riskin unit at Warners for the title role in "The Life of John Doe."

A merit system for the selection of high school principals, assistant superintendents and other officials has been agreed upon by the Boards of Superintendents and Examiners, it was learned yesterday. Under the plan, cooperation will replace independent action of the two boards in the selection of candidates.

ST. LOUIS, March 18 (AP)--The Post-Dispatch answered a contempt of court citation today with a an assertion that publication of two editorials and a cartoon relating to the Neck-Brady extortion case was to "render a public service" and to strengthen "public confidence in and respect for the courts."

Former State Senator Ellwood M. Rabenold, who has been on trial in General Sessions Court charged with violating the State Banking Law, was found guilty shortly after midnight on three of eighteen counts.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Senator Smith of South Carolina, who survived the Presidential "purge," exclaimed in the Senate today that if he were Governor of Georgia "there would be another secession call."
WASHINGTON, March 18--Diplomate failed to discern any real prospect of peace in the meeting today of Chancellor Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini.
MADRID, March 18--A commercial treaty between Great Britain and Spain, far more comprehensive than the barter agreement reached between France and Spain two...

KANSAS CITY, March 18 (AP)-- Matthew S. Murray, two-job wheelhorse of the Pendergast Democratic machine, was sentenced today to two years in Federal prison for evading income taxes, and another machine lieutenant, R. Emmet O'Malley, came back from prison to face two State bribery indictments.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 18 (UP)--The Soviet Union has given formal diplomatic assurance that it will have no further territorial demands in Northwestern Europe, it was revealed tonight by a Swedish Foreign Office spokesman.

BERLIN, March 18--The formation of a three-power entente including Germany, Italy and Russia is accepted in informed quarters tonight as one of the concrete developments issuing from today's consultations between Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini at Brennero.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Citing the present armed struggle "for possession of the remnants of the natural resources of two ancient continents" as an object lesson that should make Americans humbly aware of the necessity of conserving their own, Secretary Ickes told...

The Western Union Telegraph Company forwarded yesterday to stockholders the proxy notice for the forthcoming annual meeting seeking the re-election of all directors and submitting six proposals to shareholders for approval or rejection.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 18--In a report to the Senate today Foreign Minister Grigore Gafencu asserted emphatically that the government was working for the maintenance of Rumania's independence and did not intend to allow the country's natural resources to be used to "serve the war aims of any one."

ALBANY, March 18--The Republican's answer to Crovernor Lehman's demand that they cut $24,800,000 from the State budget by centralizing rural school districts up-State came tonight from Irving M. Ives, Assembly majority leader, who denied that any such savings could be effected and offered figures to show that the effect of centralization would be to increase rather than decrease State spending for education.

Sixteen-year-old Miss Gloria Callen, representing the Women's Swimming Association, captured the metropolitan senior 100-yard backstroke championship at the A.A.U. meet conducted in the Hotel St. George pool, Brooklyn, last night.

HONG KONG, March 18--An official announcement will shortly be forthcoming from Tokyo to the effect that following the reopening of the Yangtze River to third-power vessels and traders, the river will, at an early date, be reopened from Nanking to Wuhu.

An issue of 125,000 shares of $4.25 preferred stock of Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company will be offered to the public today by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Shields Co., Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch Co.

After almost four hours' debate, the Board of Higher Education refused early this morning, by a vote of 11 to 7, to reconsider the appointment of Bertrand Russell, British philosopher, mathematician and author, as Professor of Philosophy at City College for a term from February, 1941, until June, 1942.

TOKYO, March 18 (UP)--Replying to questions by Kozo Yamamoto, leading member of the Minseito, Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita said in the Diet today that nego tiations had been-started with Russia for conclusion of a permanent fisheries treaty, which would go into effect when the present oneyear agreement expires at the end of this year. The outlook for this treaty is good, he said.

The Investment Bankers Association of America has lost no time in launching its program of aggressive agitation for relief from certain provisions of the securities laws and regulations which, it alleges, are the principal factors blocking the flow of capital into industry.
PARIS, March 18--Along the Rhine today there were echoes of the meeting between Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini on the Brenner.

Peace talk, together with a hesitant attitude on the part of buyers, led yesterday to declining prices in scrap metals, rags and waste paper as the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, Inc., began its three-day annual convention at the Hotel Astor.

Price-cutting, in which refrigerator manufacturers engaged in the first two months of the year, has begun to spread to the retail field here, despite Feld-Crawford price maintenance contracts in this area, it became known yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 18 --In one of the tightest finishes of the season, Bull Whip, representing the Brandywine Stable of Donald P. Ross, earned a photo decision over Technician, last year's Flamingo Stakes winner, in the St. Patrick Purse at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)-- The War and Navy Departments, represented as skeptical but open to conviction, consented today to tests to determine whether a new type of liquid oxygen bomb is the most deadly destroyer yet devised by man or merely a substitute equivalent of the TNT now in general military use.

DETROIT, March 18--Arguments over whether the Michigan Manufacturers Association has the right to intervene in the case involving unemployment benefits for Chrysler Corporation employee made idle in the strike of last Fall were held here today before the appeal board of the Michigan Unemployment Compensation Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 18--A United States ship, the freighter Weet Camargo of the Pacific Argentine Brazil Line, was halted by French cruiser well within the American safety zone on Feb. 25, an announcement by the State Department today revealed.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 18-- Major Philip Rhinelander, a member of one of New York City's oldest and most distinguished families, veteran of the old Seventh Regiment of the National Guard and a large owner of New York City real estate, died unexpectedly today at the Long Beach Hospital, where he had undergone an abdominal operation on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Negotiations of the Allied purchasing missions with United States manufacturers are going ahead despite the Congressional investigation of foreign airplane procurement, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Representative Howard W. Smith of Virginia, chairman of the Committee to Investigate the National Labor Relations Board, declared today that the law against government officials lobbying for or against Congressional appropriations was "clear and explicit," and he called upon Attorney General Robert H. Jackson to proceed against members and officials of the Labor Board.

Voicing fears of sabotage to new aircraft engines en route by rail to West Coast warplane plants, Eastern railroads held a hearing yesterday on their own proposal to raise freight rates 30 to 60 per cent to cover additional insurance on shipments of aircraft equipment.

Mrs. Leonidas J. Calvocoressi, a vice chairman of the general committee for the benefit luncheon and bridge party to be given April 9 in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre under the auspices of the Friends of the Near East, will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 46 East Ninety-second Street, for a group of young matrons and debutantes of former years who are assisting with plans for the benefit.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18--A plan to decide next Summer on a substitute Democratic candidate for Senator from Pennsylvania if the party did not nominate the "right" man at the primary April 23 was imputed to President Roosevelt today by John B. Kelly, chairman of the Democratic City Committee.

ALBANY, March 18--The State Tax Commission said today that neither the two-cent State nor the one-cent New York City sales tax on cigarettes could be deducted by consumers from the State income tax payments, due April 15.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 18-- A boat from the Western Long Island Sound fleet, John White's Shucks, came through to victory today as a dozen Star Class craft began competition in the annual Johnny Walker Cup series.

The loan exhibition of Italian Renaissance portraits, held for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 18--The Federal Reserve Board reported today a sharp drop in industrial production from January to February, carrying forward the decline from the record levels of late 1939.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP)--Willie Hoppe of New York won his sixth straight victory tonight in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament, maintaining an unbeaten record as he defeated Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., 50 to 32, in fifty-seven innings. The veteran cue star had a high run of five.

A judgment for $5,949 was docketed yesterday against Father Divine in the New York County Clerk's office as 600 disciples of the Negro cult leader picketed in front of the county court house in Foley Square.

In 1938, for the fourteenth consecutive year, the League of Nations issued the "Armaments Year Book." Yesterday the International Documents Service of the Columbia University Press announced that there would be no 1939 edition of the year book.
Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson approved yesterday the partial settlement of a suit entered on behalf of the Continental Securities Corporation by Arthur A. Ballantine, trustee.

Although uncertainty over the significance of the diplomatic activities in Europe carried prices of cotton in Liverpool off the full 25 points permitted in one day, the market on the Cotton Exchange here recovered part of an early loss of 10 points yesterday and ended with net losses of 2 to 6 points.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously reversed yesterday the recent conviction of second degree perjury returned in Special Sessions Court, Queens, against Frank A. Erickson, the nationally known bookmaker whom Mayor La Guardia threatened to deport from the city.

MARSHFIELD, Mass., March 19 --Sir John Henry Lee Fagge, former gardener in Pepperell, who became tenth Baronet of Fagge ten years ago, died late yesterday at his home here at the age of 71.

LONDON, March 20 (AP)--British Board of Trade figures for February reported today imports at 95,630,000, exports of British products 37,400,000, re-exports 2,430,000, total exports 39,830,000, excess of imports 55,800,000.
The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania sailed from her West Fourteenth Street pier last night at 8 o'clock, ending three months of idleness in the Port of New York to venture again on the high seas.

The Air Reduction Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiary companies, in the annual report for 1939, to be made public today by C.E. Adams, chairman, andCharles S. Munson, president, reveals a net income of $5,076,825 ...

Now that Bill Sharpe, who kept the world informed as to the hunting and fishing opportunities of North Carolina, has left the Fish and Game Department to realize the traditional newspaper man's dream of publishing a weekly, his portfolio has dropped into the capable lap of Bob Thompson.
ROME, March 20--Under-Secretary of State Summer Welles sailed for home from Genoa today to the accompaniment of a salvo of antipeace comment in the Italian press.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- The Bureau of Mines estimated today the April market demand for domestic crude oil at 3,550,000 barrels daily, or a total of 106,500,000. This is 1 per cent (49,000 barrels) more than the estimated demand for March and 2 per cent more than the actual demand last April.

After hearing twenty young musicians chosen from a thousand who have been auditioned in the NYA Radio Workshop at 1,697 Broadway, Leopold Stokowski yesterday discussed his plan to organize his All-American Youth Orchestra and take it on a tour of Central and South America in July and August.

Acting on the theory that rebuilding of outmoded neighborhoods in the city should not be left entirely to public enterprise, New York, realty, planning and commercial organizations have joined hands to press for adoption of a State Legislative bill aimed to encourage private capital to take over a major part of this rehabilitation job.

As events continued to indicate that the Allies were preparing to pursue a more intensive campaign against the Nazi forces, and with more rebuffs showered on the peace reports, the stock market made yesterday a further recovery.

Ever since Chuck Fenske broke the world indoor three-quarter mile dirt track record with a 2:59.7 last Saturday, Daniel J. Ferris has been wrestling with a problem. He had Wisconsin Chuck lined up for the mile and a half event at the Finnish Relief Fund track carnival at Madison Square Garden a week ...
Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Wing Jr. of 113 East Sixty-seventh Street will return today from a cruise in Southern waters.

ANAHEIM, Calif., March 20 (AP)-- Professor C. McGillicuddy, better known as Connie Mack, still is carrying on extensive Spring experiments with his Philadelphia baseball aggregation, but early returns indicate that his Athletics of 1940 will be a vastly improved club over last year.

RAMGARH, India, March 20 (UP)--The fifty-third annual All-In dia Nationalist Congress concluded its sessions today by voting to Mohandas K. Gandhi power to direct the future program for freedom from British rule.

PARIS, March 20--Dramatically in the last hours, but following a long series of incidents that steadily indicated the probability of that finale, Premier Edouard Daladier resigned today, and of course his entire Cabinet resigned with him.

LOS ANGELES, March 20--Ferdinand Ellerman, nationally known astronomer and a pioneer in modern solar photography who for 33 years was on the staff of the Mount Wilson Observatory, succumbed to a long illness today at the Queen of the Angels Hospital. He was 71 years old.

A lien for $129,076 was filed against Baroness Eugene de Rothschild in Federal court yesterday. The Baroness recently was chosen the seventh best dressed woman in the world in a poll of Parisian dressmakers.

It is hardly the fault of M. Daladier if France feels a vague dissatisfaction with the conduct of the war. The baker's son from the hills of the Vaucluse has been a good war leader. The peasants and shopkeepers have been able to understand him and trust him.

Governor Lehman's proposal to divert $60,000,000 of unexpended gradecrossing funds for the purpose of making highway intersections safer has drawn criticism in the Legislature. The Republicans say that he is abandoning the pay-as-you-go plan of highway construction and advance other objections.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The next session of Congress may be faced with another Hatch bill, forbidding private contributions to Presidential campaign funds and providing appropriations of Treasury funds for legitimate election expenses.

Another step aimed at curbing advertising allowances which it believes are discriminatory under the Robinson-Patman Act will be taken today by the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers when it will send letters to all piece goods ...

Senator Ernest Lundeen, Minnesota Farmer-Laborite, urged "absolute neutrality in the quarrels of Europe and trade with all" last night before about 600 persons at a dinner of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATLANTA, March 20--O. John Rogge, assistant attorney general of the United States, fresh from the Long-busting campaign in Louisiana, conferred with the law-enforcement agencies here today to determine if a wave of floggings by a band of night-riders in this area warranted a Federal inquiry.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (UP)-- Bertrand Russell, English philosopher, mathematician and "advanced" thinker on sex problems, said tonight he was delighted with his appointment to the faculty at City College in New York.
You would not take Steve Kaslov for a king. You would look at his 300 pounds, at his soiled heavy-silk shirt and his sausage-thick fingers and you would say he was the town butcher on a day off.

LONDON, March 20--The explanation for decreasing Allied war orders in the United States was indicated today in a statement by Edward Leslie Burgin, Minister of Supply, about the expansion of home industrial production, which, as it develops, decreases British dependence on foreign supplies.
ALBANY, March 20--The Legislature ended its formal sessions for the week today, with the leaders still hoping for adjournment at the end of next week.

A showdown on the plan for selfregulation in the liquor industry was postponed for a month here yesterday when Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, executive director of the Distilled Spirits Institute and author of the plan, asked directors of the institute to defer action on his proposal for that period.

PARIS, March 20--With the Spring sowing beginning, the Germans in occupied Poland are extending their grip ,on the country's economic life, it is learned here. About 2,500,000 independent Polish peasants have been ordered to turn over to the occupation authorities the greater part of all they produce.

Lew Jenkins of Sweetwater, Texas, who came up the hard way through the small boxing clubs to gain a place in the spotlight, will be the next challenger for the lightweight championship, now held by Lou Ambers.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 20-- This Winter resort, lying in the foothills of the majestic Sawtooth Mountain range at an elevation of 6,000 feet, truly is a skiers' paradise. Four years ago, W. Averell Harriman, New York sportsman and skiing enthusiast, started a ...

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- The Census Bureau announced today in its final ginning report for the 1939-40 season that the cotton crop in 1939 totaled 11,812,281 equivalent 500-pound bales of lint cotton. The Department of Agriculture estimated 11,792,000 bales for the crop last December.

The first day of Spring at the 1940 World's Fair in New York found yesterday 3,000 men engaged on construction and improvement work. Among them was a large crew of painters engaged to brighten the exposition for the opening on May 11.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- An insurance broker agreed today to obtain for the Federal Power Commission a detailed financial statement of payments made by operating companies in the Associated Gas and Electric System under various insurance contracts.

Only the churlish are disposed to be critical of the weather on the first day of Spring. Yesterday, full of sunshine, though a bit on the cool and blustery side, would have passed with good marks regardless of the calendar.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., March 20-- Johnny Longden, veteran jockey, easily took the riding honors today when he booted home four winners at Tanforan.

The pound sterling weakened under pressure of foreign selling in the open market here yesterday, and the final quotation of $3.71 indicated a net decline on the day of 3 cents. There was a corresponding drop of 2 points in the ...

Paul Reynaud, who has been asked by President Lebrun to succeed Edouard Daladier as Premier of France, believes Europe must undergo a far-reaching economic reorganization to permit free trade if peace after the present war "is to be something more than another brief armistice between two conflicts."

WASHINGTON, March 20--The unexpected and sudden resignation of the French Cabinet, attended by the equally unexpected refusal of M. Daladier to form new group, lends pertinence and interest to an analysis of his country's war problems which was recently made privately by a French observer.

A fourteen-room apartment in 120 East End Avenue has been leased to Archibald G. Thacher through the office of Vincent Astor, it was announced yesterday. Another large apartment in the same building was leased to Dr. Edward P. Carter.

The vacant plot, 166 by 105 feet, on the west side of Carpenter Avenue, 277 feet south of East 224th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by the W.D.A. Corporation from the Maxam Holding Corporation and will be improved with a new six-story apartment house.

An election of a board of directors of Sydenham Hospital, Manhattan Avenue and 123d Street, held there last night, was reported to have eliminated the last of the adherents of Gustavus A. Rogers, former president of the institution, whose policies were said to have caused more than 140 doctors to submit their resignations last January.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Despite warnings that a choice must be made between unbudgeted benefits for agriculture and either the levying of new taxes or an increase in the $45,000,000,000 Federal debt limit, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to appropriate $212,000,000 for parity payments to farmers.

PARIS, March 20--Repercussions of the Brenner talk between Chancellor Hitler and Premier Mussolini, a subject that remains uncommented on by official quarters, were seen in the hurried departure this afternoon of the Russian Ambassador, Alexander Shkhartzeff, for Moscow. He left by a special plane.

With beer linage in New York newspapers since the start of the year running sharply ahead of the like 1939 period, advertising campaigns during the Spring and Summer are expected to reach a postrepeal high, agency executives reported yesterday.

The National Youth Administration discontinued yesterday a project under which the Federal Government had been paying the wages of twenty two part-time clerks assigned to work in the New York offices of the American Youth Congress.

CHICAGO, March 20--The veteran Willie Hoppe of New York, undefeated in the world three-cushion billiard tournament, ran his string of victories to seven tonight by disposing of Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., 50 to 41, in forty innings.

Yesterday's vote of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, favoring the bill to stop our Government's compulsory purchase of foreign silver, was to be expected from any intelligent legislative body.

ALBANY, March 20--Compulsory semi-annual inspection of the State's 2,600,000 automobiles at a cost of 50 cents for each inspection is provided in the Rapp bill passed today by the Assembly, 113 to 27. The Commissioner of Motor Vehicles will license garages, one garage for each 500 cars, at an annual fee of $10 to make the inspections, and the garages will retain the $1 which they collect each year from the car-owners.

Several hundred persons attended funeral services yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, for Major Philip Rhinelander. Many of them are prominent in social and military life.

LONDON, March 20--The stock markets generally were quiet today but a cheerful sentiment was encouraged by the rise in national revenue to more than 1,000,000,000 and Prime Minister Chamberlain's vigorous speech yesterday. Prices hesitated on news of Premier Daladier's resignation but showed a hardening tendency toward the close.

Acting through the United Construction Workers Organizing Committee, its affiliate in the building field, the Congress of Industrial Organizations challenged yesterday the American Federation of Labor to a finish battle in the industry by asking the Building Trades Employers Association to recognize the C.I.O.

Securities of McKesson Robbins, Inc., on Tuesday, next, will be ordered returned to trading on the New York Stock Exchange, unless present plans are changed. The debentures, preferred stock and common stock have been suspended from dealings since early December, 1938, when the public first ...

Pleading for the cooperation of all organizations interested in the problems of unemployed youth, so that most effective ways might be devised to find jobs for them, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned in an address last night that unless young people now drifting in idleness received an opportunity to lead independent, creative lives they would give ear "to any one who may come along" and complicate enormously the difficult situation now confronting society.

LONDON, March 20--Weakness in European commodities became pronounced last week. Rubber was down to below 1s a pound and cotton was well below 8d, and finally tin receded to the level that held before the recent quota reduction.

WASHINGTON, March 20--J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, in a statement today declared that if Trial Examiner Mapes Davidson of Orange, N.J., had learned of Communist activity among board employes he should have reported it to the board.

The Packard Motor Car Company and its subsidiaries yesterday reported for 1939 a net profit of $545,867 after depreciation, unrealized foreign exchange loss, adjustment of security values to market, Federal income taxes and other charges.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 20 --Secretary of the Navy Charles Edison announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey.
LONDON, March 20--British officials were not so surprised by the fall of the French Government today as by the fact that Premier Edouard Daladier declined to form a new Cabinet.

A resolution calling for greater economy and efficiency in publicwelfare and relief work carried on in this State was adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Taxpayers Federation of the State of New York.

CHICAGO, March 20--Wheat showed more activity today. A much broader outside interest was reported on the buying side and with the reinstating of recently soldout lines and short covering prices soared about 3 cents a bushel to the best levels since Feb. 26.

Paul Reynaud, a leader in the group of Democratic and Social Action and financial expert, is one of the strongest men in French public life. A moderate in politics, he enjoys the confidence of the French electorate, and in the turbulent political events of recent years he has demonstrated ability to get along with all important sections of the French people, including organized labor.

In a brief and bitter battle that turned Fifth Avenue into a rioting, free-for-all arena, 350 policemen, mounted and afoot, frustrated an attempt by twenty-three pickets to stage a demonstration in front of the French Consulate at 5 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Wiretapping if deemed essential in criminal cases by government investigators, might be authorized by Federal judges in the same manner as search warrants are issued, Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, suggested today.

Ignoring the ultimatum issued against them to reinstate by yesterday Miss Mary B.C. Byrne, members of the Board of Education yesterday prepared to appeal to State Commissioner of Education Frank P. The National Academy of Basketball Arts and Sciences, modeled on the pattern of its Hollywood counter part, came into being at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln last night. The scribes awarded a few "Oscars" themselves.

In high spirits because of their victory over the Bruins in the opening game of the Series A play-offs for the Stanley Cup, the Rangers left for Boston yesterday confident that they would come through again in the second contest tonight.

Retail credit collections increased 1.15 per cent in February, according to the index of twenty local stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 45.95, against 44.08 in February of last year.

LONDON, March 20--Whatever military value last night's series of air attacks on Hoernum at the southern tip of the Island of Sylt may have had, it was overshadowed by its political and psychological effects.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The United States Consulate General in Warsaw was closed and its staff left for Berlin today following Germany's decision to evacuate the members of the diplomatic and consular establishments of all foreign governments in the part of Poland it occupies. Today was set as the deadline.
NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP)-- A Federal appellate court today lifted a jail sentence threat from Governor E.D. Rivers of Georgia, at least temporarily.

ALBANY, March 20--Faced with a recent ruling by the State Tax Commission that neither the twocent State nor the one-cent New York City sales tax on cigarettes were deductible by consumers from the State income tax payments, the Legislature started a bi-partisan move today to write exemption provisions for the cigarette taxes into the law.
LONDON, March 20--Britons plan to observe Easter as usual although some believe Good Friday will be "Der Tag."

WASHINGTON, March 20--Internal revenue collections in the first seven months of the current fiscal year were $182,574,376 less than in the same period last year, the Treasury Department announced today.

John Froscome, a 92-year-old squatter, was finally forced yesterday morning to leave the dilapidated hut he had built three years ago on Purdy Avenue, between Parker Street and St. Raymond's Avenue, the Bronx, in the shadows of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's $50,000,000 Parkchester housing development.

The health of nearly 300,000 workers in dangerous trades in New York State is better safeguarded than it was three and a half years ago as a result of the industrial hygiene program instituted by the State Labor Department on July 1, 1936, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State ...

PINEHURST, N.C., March 20-- Any of the contestants in the North and South open golf championship who failed to take Ben Hogan's farewells seriously yesterday became convinced today that the 140pound ex-Texan really meant them when he fired his sensational sixunder-par 66 at his rivals in the opening round of the tournament.

IT isn't often that a talking point escapes Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, but it's the opin ion in this corner that Hizzoner is missing a trick. It must be that the New York City climate has among its many ingredients some specific that is good for first basemen. It might be developed as a civic industry to offset some of the alleged drift out of town.

BERLIN, March 20--Chancellor Hitler today appointed Major Gen. Fritz Todt Minister for Arms and Munitions in addition to his titles of Inspector General of the German Road System and Inspector General of the German Building Industry. The new position is stated to be primarily for improving the organization of production, in which General Todt excels.

ALBANY, March 20--The Legislature is scheduled to pass at this session a bill ending the double taxation on odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange, it became known today. At the same time the hope that a reduction in the stock transfer rates generally could be put through have come to an end.

Spring, which arrived officially at 1:24 P.M. was ushered into the city yesterday with a chill thirty-milean-hour wind and the sunny day was followed by a steady rain at night. The metropolis, however, was more fortunate than the rest of the State and a good deal of the nation.

The names of seventy-nine distinguished men and women who have been nominated for the ninth quinquennial election to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on the Bronx campus, of New York University were announced late yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

Service charges for customers of New York Stock Exchange firms, which lasted twelve days in 1938 and which have endured for fewer than twenty-one days in their 1940 revival, once again are under fire.

NANKING, China, March 20-- During the first meeting of the Central Political Council today, under the chairmanship of Wang Chingwei, leader of the "orthodox" Kuomintang, steps were taken for the establishment of the Japanese-sponsored "Central Chinese Government" on March 30.

Bickford's, Inc., the restaurant chain, will have a unit of modernistic design as the result of a lease it has signed for the store at 505 Fifth Avenue, where extensive alterations will be made on the front and interior from plans by F. Russell Stuckert, architect. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and D.H. Woodruff were the brokers.

Mayor La Guardia began his annual "budget retreat" at 9:30 yesterday morning at the office of Budget Director Kenneth Dayton, in the Manhattan Municipal Building. He began preparation of the next budget.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Roberts Hillard gave a farewell dinner last night in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle for Mr. and Mrs. C. Victor Barry, who are sailing on Saturday for Europe. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Reyburn, Mr. and Mrs. F. Everett Abbott, Mrs. Marion M. ...

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 (AP)--Ted Williams hit a home run inside the park for the only score as the Red Sox handed the Cardinals their first shutout of the year today.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 20 (UP)--Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N.C., flashed around the 6,700-yard championship course today in 74 to win the twelfth annual Mid-South women's tournament, 26 strokes ahead of her nearest competitor.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 20 --Gay American, 4-year-old bay son of American Flag, carried Mrs. W. T. Anderson's red, white and green banner to victory in the Stuart Purse of a mile and a sixteenth at Tropical Park today. Favored at 11 to 5 in the field of seven, the gelding defeated The Thrush by a half length in 1:44 2-5.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The House Labor Committee disapproved several proposed amendments to the National Labor Relations Act today and defeated an attempt to reconsider its approval of a motion to add two members to the present three-man National Labor Relations Board.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20--Mrs. Elizabeth Hornung, co-founder and, since 1925, president of the Jacob Hornung Brewery Company of this city, died at her home in Mount Airy today of bronchial pneumonia. She was 88 years old.

Unless compelled to "execute our obligations," or faced with aggression, the Turkish Republic will continue its policy of peace and friendship with its neighbors and with the Great Powers, Mehmet Munir Ertegun, Turkish Minister ...

WASHINGTON, March 20--An ambitious plan calling for an exchange of Pacific and North Atlantic trade routes by the United States and Great Britain and calculated to use American shipping, tied up under the Neutrality Act, is receiving the attention of the Maritime Commission and may soon be taken up officially with British authorities, who have been interested in the project by Ambassador Kennedy.

ALBANY, March 20--Governor Lehman asked the Legislature today to appropriate $50,000 to carry on the work of the special grand jury investigating alleged illicit liquor traffic and the conduct of officials in Orange County, with the money to be repaid to the State by the county, on which the cost of investigation is a legal charge.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The financial worth of the America motion picture industry is estimated at more than $2,000,000,000 in an analysis by the Department of Commerce made public today by Nathan D. Golden on the basis of information supplied by the industry.

With prices of cotton in Liverpool up the full 25 points permitted in one session, a recovery of $1 a bale occurred on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. The market ended with net gains of 13 to 19 points. Liquidation resulting from undoing of straddles between here and Bombay failed to halt the upward movement.

The program of Louis Kaufman's violin recital at the Town Hall last night mustered some music of recent vintage. Hottest off the griddle and most amusing was "Hexapoda" by Robert Russell Bennett, which had its first performance with the composer at the piano. Mr. Bennett's subtitle is "Five Studies in Jitteroptera," which has a scientific look in print but which had a gay, impudent sound in the hall.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)-- Senator Minton of Indiana called today in the Senate for an inquiry into the reorganization of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation to prevent what he termed benefits for "bankers, financial lawyers and stock manipulators."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 20-- The final link in a project once known as the "Berlin to Baghdad Railway," which was one of the pet schemes of former Kaiser Wilhelm three and a half decades ago and which, it was hoped, would facilitate Germany's eastward push, will be finished within two months--by the British.

BALTIMORE, March 20--The American Dental Association completed this afternoon its, three-day review of a hundred years of professional achievement in the United States, a session commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Baltimore College of Dental Surgery, the first in the world.

An audience which packed the auditorium listened last night to the performance of Wagner's "Parsifal," given for the benefit of Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Medical and Social Work in Labrador and North Newfoundland.
DENVER, March 20 (AP)--Denver's Nuggets, defending their championship, and two other seeded teams made their way into the quarterfinals of the National A.A.U. basketball tournament tonight.

Following the lead of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, the State Mediation Board intervened yesterday in the economic struggle between Aunt Martha's Luncheon Combination Service and seven striking delivery boys.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 20--An Italian-Rumanian trade agreement signed here today provides for the pupchase by Italy this year of 454,000 tons of oil and oil products, including 105,000 tons of gasoline, 107,000 tone of oil residue and 110,000 tons of crude petroleum. These figures are slightly higher than last year's but far below those of 1936, when Italy bought 1,664,890 tons.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures which will be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Reports from 21,839 independent retail stores in thirty-four States reveal a decline of 2.5 per cent in sales in February as compared with January, but a gain of 10 per cent over February, 1939, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 20--The validity, as well as the propriety, of the income questions in the 1940 census schedules was questioned in the official report of the Senate Commerce Committee, filed today in support of the Tobey resolution seeking the deletion of the questions.

Four bond issues are to be suspended from New York Stock Exchange dealings on March 20 because of the small amounts outstanding and the small aggregate market value of each issue.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20--A question of weighty significance for the Yankees will come up for consideration tomorrow when the champions face the Boston Bees at Waterfront Park. The matter has to do with the condition of Lefty Gomez's pitching arm and ...

ROME, March 21--For Italy the formation of the Paul Reynaud government is an unpleasant shock, which widens the gap between this country and France and makes even slimmer the already very slim chance of the Allies obtaining Rome's support.

Pork supplies were very heavy, steer beef and veal about normal; other classes moderate in yesterday's local market. Fresh pork cuts were steady to slightly lower; old crop lamb slightly stronger and some sales Spring lamb lower. Prices otherwise were mostly unchanged.

A check for $6,000 will be turned over to the Finnish Relief Fund today by the National Ski Association, it was announced yesterday by Roger Langley, president of the association. With the check will be a request asking that the money be used to aid families of members of Finnish ski associations.

LONDON, March 21--On the eve of the Easter holiday, the stock markets today were extremely slack and few outstanding movements took place. Gilt-edge securities maintained their overnight levels, but French bonds eased in the foreign group on political news from France.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21 (AP) --Ohio became baseball's newest 1940 "holdout" today, with Tax Commissioner William S. Evatt demanding a larger "cut" for the State from all the organized clubs within Buckeye borders.

For the first time since the Rolls razor was introduced in this country thirteen years ago, the bulk of this year's advertising campaign will go into newspapers, Robert G. Brown, president and general manager, announced yesterday. In previous years the company used national magazines chiefly.

An ancient rite that originated in the Roman catacombs early in the Christian era was observed here yesterday morning in the Episcopal Church of San Salvatore, 359 Broome Street. Members of the Italian families of the neighborhood entered the church silently, placed under a twenty-foot cross their offerings consisting of small wheat and lentil plants, and then knelt in prayer.

By an overwhelming vote the Senate has approved an appropriation not made by the House of $212,000,000 for parity payments to farmers, and has voted an additional appropriation of $85,000,000 for the purchase and distribution of surplus commodities.

Widespread interest was shown yesterday in the women's apparel trades in Mayor La Guardia's discourse on styles, designers and the role of the city's fashion industries before the Fashion Group. A number of apparel authorities expressed their congratulations to the Mayor for focusing attention on this city as the "fashion center."

BOSTON, March 21--The Bruins came back into their own tonight. The National Hockey League champions spotted the speedy New York Rangers one goal early in the first period, then rallied to hand the visitors a 4-to-2 setback.

HAVANA, March 21--The Cuban All-Star baseball team routed the Cincinnati Reds today at Tropical Stadium, 11 to 7, in the first of three games. A crowd of some 7,000 gleefully witnessed the Reds' discomfiture.

Analysis of Wednesday's 14-to-4 vote of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, in favor of prohibiting future purchases of foreign silver, shows that the four votes in the negative-- Senators Wagner, Barkley, Bankhead and Smathers--were all Administration supporters.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Secretary Ickes, a third-term advocate, declared today at a press conference that those who wanted President Roosevelt for a third term were not wavering, despite yesterday's announcement by Postmaster General Farley that his name would be presented to the Democratic National Convention at Chicago.

Following a recovery of more than $1 a bale from the low levels of the week, fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange held yesterday within unusually narrow limits and ended with net changes ranging from a loss of 3 to a gain of 5 points.

Bank clearings for the week rose sharply above the volume for the preceding period, aided by tax payments and the usual mid-month settlements. The total for the country however, was again smaller than in the corresponding week last year, due to the continued drop below a year ago at New York.

According to testimony in Federal court yesterday, the bankers who financed Philip Musica, the ex-convict, in his rise to domination of McKesson Robbing, Inc., met him first in 1925 under his assumed name of F. Donald Coster as a suspected bootlegger.

Despite the war in Europe and its resultant effect on foreignowned passenger ships that would ordinarily be leaving New York today and tomorrow with thousands of Easter vacationists, the few lines that have scheduled cruises yesterday announced capacity bookings for almost every vessel.

Mrs. George Eustis Corcoran gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 235 East Seventy-third Street, for Baroness de Villiers Terrage, chairman of the committee in charge of the American Appeal for the Lafayette Fund, which supplies kits of necessities to French soldiers.

ALBANY, March 21--The Dunnigan Pari-Mutuel Bill to permit betting on horse races at State tracks was reported out of the Senate Finance Committee today, and will be brought up for a vote early next week.

Detectives of the Morrisania station in the Bronx were puzzled yesterday over this arithmetical problem: if five crates of apples are supposedly removed from 164 crates delivered to a Department of Welfare distributing station, still leaving 164 crates, where did the five crates come from?

ALBANY, March 21--The passage of a bill affecting Mayor La Guardia's pension rights is being held up in the Legislature awaiting a "home rule" message from the Mayor and the City Council, it became known today. The bill would curtail drastically the benefits receivable by the Mayor should he retire from office at the end of his present term.

Dr. Thomas Drysdale Buchanan, the dean of New York anesthetists and the oldest practicing physician in the city to devote his time solely to anesthesia, died last night at his home, 2,345 Broadway, after a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

The 4-to-1 vote in the Assembly in favor of the Rapp bill--establishing periodic compulsory inspection for the 2,600,000 automobiles of the State--reflects a very general belief among motor vehicle administrators and safety workers that such inspection is a worth-while step.

The Cunard White Star liner Lancastria arrived in port yesterday after a stormy crossing that resulted in painful injuries to seven seamen, three of whom were still in the ship's hospital at docking time.

TOKYO, March 21--Japan's relations with Western powers are in a state of suspense pending results of the great etperiment that Wang Ching-wei is now introducing at Nanking. Investments in multi-family properties yesterday included the purchase by a client of Harold M. Silverman, broker, of the seven-story elevator apartment house at 601 West 112th Street, northwest corner of Broadway.

WASHINGTON, March 21--A public debt of any amount up to $50,000,000,000 would not worry Secretary Morgenthau, he said at his press conference today, but he categorically denounced any "trick" or "roundabout" methods for circumventing the present statutory debt limit of $45,000,000,000.
Plans were filed yesterday for the erection of an apartment house on Kingston Avenue, in Brooklyn, to cost $382,000.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Homer A.A. Smith, chief purchasing agent and head of the Washington office for the Panama Canal, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the age of 65.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 21--On the lawn of his home on the Venetian causeway that, from island unto island, joins the mainland and Miami Beach in this sector, stood the squat, round-headed, square-shouldered, sun-tanned form of His Royal Highness of the baseball realm, the Emperor Klem, whose word has been law on the National League diamonds since 1904.

WASHINGTON, March 21--At long last, by the statement he made yesterday at Springfield, Mass., Postmaster General Farley has openly opposed himself to the third nomination draft, a position he has privately maintained since the draft began.

The Clyde-Mallory Line, a veteran steamship company in the New York-Gulf passenger and freight trade, announced last night that it would establish a new service between New York and Houston, offering fast freight and passenger sailines between New York and the modern Texas port for the first time.

Tomorrow night will mark the eighth and final performance at the Biltmore, of "Goodbye in the Night," the melodrama dealing with a homicidal maniac.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 (UP)--The Swedish Government, which still would like to conclude a Scandinavian defensive alliance with Norway and Finland, despite Soviet objections, announced today that as part of new defense measures the military class of 1933, totaling 10,000 men, would be called up for 150 days of training this year and 64 days next year.

Edward A.E.P. Samson is different from most cartographers. When he puts Sakhalin on a new map, or Shikuka; when he inserts Kilwa or Kivinge, Tobago or Bucaramanga he can shut his pale eyes and see these places. He has been to them.

All important securities and commodity markets in the United, States and generally throughout the world will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. All banks in this city, however, will be open as usual, as will livestock markets throughout the country.

Larger quarters in Rockefeller Center will be taken by the Jacqueline Cochran Cosmetics Company because of its expanding business. The concern, headed by Miss Cochran, the aviatrix, will move from 420 Lexington Avenue to new offices and a display room in the International Building. The change of location will be made about April 15.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 21--So far as the official records go, the Giants and Tigers engaged in no contest today. But before an itinerant thunderstorm cracked down and wrecked their ball game in the upper half of the fourth inning, with the Giants leading, 6 to 0, enough had happened to put Colonel Bill Terry into one of his merrier moods.

The first Spring lamb, from California, has arrived. The lambs are full grown and just in time for Easter dinner. The fore quarters, weighing nine to eleven pounds, are 28 cents a pound. Hind quarters, a little heavier, are 38 cents a pound; legs are 35 cents, shoulder cuts are 25.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 (AP) --James Woods, widely known former hotel manager, died last night at the age of 72.

Reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City increased their holdings of United States Government bonds $5,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a further new high record of $2,505,000,000, according to figures released yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 21--Prices of wheat advanced about cent a bushel in the early trading today to a new high on the current upturn. The May was 6 1/8 cents above the low on Tuesday. Profit-taking and evening up for the holiday tomorrow, combined with hedging ...

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21--The refunding of $279,160 tolls collected unlawfully on the Hutchinson River Parkway probably will begin in the Westchester County Court House here tomorrow morning, Commissioner of Finance Herbert C. Gerlach announced this evening.

NANKING, China, March 21--The most important resolution adopted by the Japanese-sponsored Central Political Conference on behalf of former Premier Wang Ching-wei today abolished the names of the "North China Provisional Government" and the "Central China Reformed Government."

The H.L. Green Company, Inc., which operates or controls the operation of retail store chains, and its domestic subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 a net income of $2,106,415 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21-- Warners today purchased "The War of the Copper Kings," by C.B. Glasscock, reportedly for $40,000, as a probable vehicle for Edward G. Robinson. The story deals with the Anaconda Copper struggle, but the film will not depict any actual historical figures.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs, who finished third in the National Hockey League eliminated the Black Hawks, fourth place finishers, from the Stanley can play-offs tonight, 2 to 1.

Mrs. Marion Ball Hoffman, former president of the New York Pan-Hellenic Association and one of the founders of Pan-Hellenic, House, Forty-ninth Street and First Avenue, died yesterday at New York Hospital after an illness of several weeks. She was 57 years old and lived at 423 West 120th Street.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 21 --P.J. McConnell's consistent 8-year-old gelding Double B turned in another game effort to win the five-and-a-half furlong fifth race, feature at Tropical Park today. Under Irving Anderson's strong handling, the veteran drove up on the outside to triumph by a neck at $9.90 for $2.

In the four and one-half years since the establishment of the WPA relief workers have built 23,000 new public buildings and made improvements or additions to 65,000 others, Colonel F.C. Harrington, National Work Projects Commissioner, reported yesterday.

France has changed her leadership in a manner that reaffirms French democracy and gives a tonic to the Allied cause. One remembers all too well the internal crises of pre-war years, when political bickering often left France without a government during critical days.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 21 --The strongest and most representative field in the history of American skiing will start in the National Ski Association's open downhill, slalom and combined championships for men and women to be held in conjunction with the Harriman Cup tournament at this Winter wonderland tomorrow and Saturday.

The State Mediation Board succeeded yesterday in settling "the biggest little labor dispute" ever to engage its attention--the strike of seven delivery boys against Aunt Martha's Luncheon Combination Service.

Badly crippled and beaten in the opening contest, Red Dutton's Americans face the crucial test at Madison Square Garden tonight, when they meet the Detroit Red Wings in the second game of the Series C hockey play-offs. A week ago Mr. La Guardia took the stump for the straight conservative ticket in art, with a blackball for futurism. WASHINGTON, March 21--The Inland Steel Company and the United Biscuit Company of America, both of Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering an aggregate of $43,000,000 of new securities, virtually all of which will be used to refinance outstanding obligations.

A 3 -year-old child was crushed to death and her mother and another woman were critically injured yesterday in an elevator accident in the apartment house at 2,020 Kings Highway, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 21--An unsuccessful effort by Russia to obtain American planes for the Loyalist Government of Spain during the Spanish revolution was disclosed today in the annual report of the National Munitions Control Board for the calendar year 1939. The board blocked it as contrary to United States neutrality statutes.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Manning Avery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Truman Mitchell Avery of New York, to John Homer Platten Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Homer Platten, also of this city, took place here yesterday afternoon in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The House Appropriations Committee asked Congress today to cut the National Labor Relations Board's request of $3,180,000 for the coming fiscal year to $2,848,000, a reduction of $337,000, because the board is overstaffed.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 21-- The fates that control the destinies of golfers finally smiled on deserving Ben Hogan, who today annexed the North and South open championship, one of the game's oldest and most esteemed fixtures, with a record total of 277 strokes.

OSLO, Norway, March 21--As a large part of the population of Norway and Sweden went out with skis today for a four or five-day Easter vacation, ominous news from both East and West obtruded upon the holiday mood as a reminder that in these times the life of a small nation is not a happy one.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Governor Lehman of New York warned today against the "danger to a democracy" which comes from religious intolerance, but ignored an invitation to proclaim Postmaster General Farley as the State's "favorite son" condidate for President.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Although failing to reach a final vote today on the Agriculture Appropriation Bill, the Senate completed action on amendments assuring passage of its full total of about $923,000,000, and approved in addition RFC loans of $40,000,000 for the electrification of rural areas and $50,000,000 for a farm-purchase program.

LONDON, March 2--While German bombers were swooping over a British convoy off the Scottish coast last night, a lone raider penetrated into the English Channel and fired the British steamship Barnhill, killing five and injuring six of her crew.

WASHINGTON, March 21--A nonprofit, non-partisan association to combat soil erosion, the waste of rainfall and the resultant human waste and displacement will hold its first meeting tomorrow. It is tentatively called Friends of the Land.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 21-- John White's Shucks of the Western Long Island Sound fleet had a substantial lead in the Star Class Spring championship for the Santa Maria Cup after finishing second today in the second race of the series being sailed off here.

Bound on the most significant voyage of her four-year career, the 81,000-ton liner Queen Mary was somewhere at sea last night, presumably overhauling her smaller sister vessel, the Mauretania, which had sailed twelve hours earlier on a similar secret mission.

PARIS, March 21--Three times during the day the doors of the Assizes Court, where forty-four former Communist Deputies are being tried in secret, were opened for the announcement of rulings by the military court.

PARIS, March 21--With the energy and decision that have characterized his whole political career, Paul Reynaud has formed a Cabinet within twenty-four hours. Tomorrow he will go before the Chamber of Deputies with his declaration of policy.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Senator Tobey failed again today in his singlehanded fight to obtain Senate consideration of his resolution disapproving the income questions which the census takers are instructed to ask during the gathering of the decennial census data starting April 1.

HOERNUM, Island of Sylt, Germany, March 21--Three United States correspondents who traveled to this German air base, raided by the British Tuesday night, saw some evidence tonight of the sevenhour bombings. CHICAGO, March 24--Corn was more active last week on the Board of Trade here than it had been recently, largely in sympathy with wheat, but the trade remained decidedly subnormal and is expected to continue so until more is known regarding the amount of grain sealed for government loans.

LONDON, March 24--Ambrose Manning, who was on the stage for nearly seventy years and was the last surviving principal of the original "Sign of the Cross" company, died in Brixham, South Devon, at the age of 79 on Good Friday. The news of his death was received here by friends in a telegram from his widow.

PITTSBURGH, March 24--A minor overall improvement in steel demand, an increase in export sales, a slight softening in some of the scrap markets and a 1-point decline in the nation-wide ingot operating rate were features in news of the industry last week.

Easter was heralded with many outdoor dawn services in the suburbs yesterday, although the attendance was cut sharply by the sub-freezing temperatures. Several of the traditional celebrations were moved indoors because of the chilling winds. Four women collapsed from the effects of the cold at a Rockland County sunrise service and frozen band instruments were a common difficulty.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 24-- One of the world's outstanding fliers for ten years, Alf Engen made two flawless leaps today to win the invitation ski jump, final event of the Harriman Cup and national championship competition.

McPherson, assistant professor of economics at Oberlin College.

Adie, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24--A thermometer which measures cold down to 259 degrees centigrade below zero has just been perfected at the United States Bureau of Standards.

BOSTON, March 24--The Bruins' speed was too much for the Rangers tonight. The fast-skating Boston sextet, playing an aggressive, alert battle, defeated the New York aggregation, 4 to 3, in a lively game that was thoroughly enjoyed by the season's record throng.
