With the delivery to Pan American Airways of the Flying Cloud, the first of its Boeing airliners designed specifically for flight "above the weather," another interesting page has been turned in the history of American air transport.

PARIS, March 24--The churches of Paris were filled this anxious Easter. The congregations comprised women of all ages, but most of the men were either very young or beyond middle age. Civilian life is already almost denuded of men under 40, and the classes of 45 are now called to serve in the war.

PARIS, March 24--The decline in both sterling and the franc on the New York market occasions no concern in financial circles here, for it is not believed there is any doubt abroad that the Allies will be able to meet their payments for war purchases.

WASHINGTON, March 24--Scores of proposals dealing with the relations of business and government will go before the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States starting April 29, the chamber disclosed today.

Special services and sermons at many of the city's synagogues yesterday morning featured the annual observance of Purim, the holiday that commemorates the defeat more than 2,500 years ago of the plot of the Persian Minister Haman to exterminate the Jewish people.

ALBANY, March 24--Calendars devoid of the usual large number of routine measures, but crowded with the principal problems of the 1940 session, will confront the members of the Legislature when they return here tomorrow for what is scheduled to be the final week of the 1940 regular session.

PARIS, March 24--Eastertide at the front was marked by a recrudescence of propaganda on the German side, especially along the banks of the Rhine. Loud-speakers, calico streamers, and tracts dropped from planes, all stressed peace and fraternization, not for getting the customary gibes at the British.

WASHINGTON, March 24--The Senate tomorrow tackles the bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act three years, with the Administration leadership confident it can deliver the legislation to the White House in the form President Roosevelt considers necessary for his foreign trade expansion program.

There was a shade of disappointment yesterday on the sidelines of Park and Fifth Avenues for those who braved the biting wind to view the Easter Parade. The fashions that all had hoped to see were blacked out by sables, silver foxes and other luxurious furs in which women huddled as they sauntered by.

LONDON, March 24--Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, indicated in a message broadcast tonight to the Finnish people as well as to Britons that, if the Allies won the war, they would try to restore to Finland the territory lost by her in the Russo-Finnish conflict.

MALMOE, Sweden, March 24 (UP) --Defense Minister Per Edvin Skoeld, asserting that Sweden is preparing to reorganize her defense on a wartime basis, announced in a speech tonight that Parliament is expected soon to pass an act providing for longer compulsory military service.

LONDON, March 24--The statement of James H.R. Cromwell, United States Minister to Canada, in his recent speech, that the future of all democracies depends on the victory of the Allies, continues to attract attention and to raise the hopes of British editorial writers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24-- "The Timers," a comedy by Bradbury Foote, has been acquired by Wesley Ruggles, Columbia producer-director, as a Vehicle for Cary Grant and Jean Arthur, Mr. Ruggles has announced.

WASHINGTON, March 24--Increases in loans, discounts, total deposits, assets and holdings of government obligations of various kinds and a decrease in holdings of other securities at a reported for 1939 by the Federal Deposit. Insurance Corporation for 13,535 insured commercial banks.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Monday, March 25--After having been blocked by snowdrifts some eighteen feet deep for about twelve hours the Laurentian, Montreal-to-New York express train, was able to proceed to New York early today after it had backed to Montreal and switched to the tracks of the Canadian National Railway.
Dr. and Mrs. Gouverneur M. Phelps have returned from Central America, and have taken an apartment at the Blackstone.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24--The Giants returned to the scenes of their former triumphs and grandeur today, but to Colonel Bill Terry, who might have enjoyed himself reflecting upon the days when he trained here under the late John J. McGraw, the day was merely another succession of chills and fever.

The pamphlet report of Best Co. for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 1940, issued yesterday by Philip Le Boutillier, president, reveals that a total of $298,566 was spent for expansion, improvements and replacements during the year, principally for air-conditioning the Fifth Avenue store and seven year-round branches, as compared with $149,148 in 1938, $421,002 in 1937, $122,444 in 1936 and $238,200 in 1935.

With the solemn pageantry of pontfical mass augmented by special music in which two Metropolitan Opera stars partcipated as soloists, the Christian feast of the risen Christ was celebrated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, with Archbishop Francis J. Spellman pontificating.
LONDON, March 24--Dr. Thomas Adams, architect and authority on town planning, who was widely known in the United States, died today in Sussex after a short illness at the age of 68.

The principal effect of the war on business in the United States may prove to be readjustment rather than expansion, the Guaranty Trust Company observes in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey. The bank believes that any trade expansion that may take place will continue to be highly selective, with stimulating effects in some lines offset by further obstacles in others.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 24--In ancient days on the diamond when there was one lone umpire to a game and the arbiter doubled as announcer, it was the custom for the umpire to start off each half inning by facing the stands and announcing: "Smith up, Jones on deck, Williams in the hole."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 24-- Easter sailing garb was a return to Winter woolens today in the dinghy regatta, at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The Resurrection of Jesus Christ was commemorated at Easter dawn services in the parks of Brooklyn, Manhattan and the suburbs yesterday morning. Raw winds and Winter temperatures chilled the shivering worshipers and curtailed the services or forced them indoors.

ALBANY, March 24--New York State's Department of Law recovered $75,900.32 in cash and securities for defrauded investors during 1939, it was disclosed in the annual report of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., made public here today.

HAVANA, March 24 (AP)--The expedition of the Reds to Cuba ended in a deadlock today as the third game of their series with the Cuban All-Stars was called in the tenth inning with the score 4 to 4 so that the Cincinnati team could catch a boat.

The report of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for 1939, released for publication today, indicates a consolidated net income of $20,236,552 after all charges, taxes and reserves, but before depletion of metal mines, equal to $2.33 each on the 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding. NASSAU, Bahamas, March 24-- John S. White, Western Long Island Sound skipper, completed his conquest of the Star Class yachting series in Bahaman waters today, adding the Santa Maria Trophy, emblematic of the Spring championship of the division, to the Johnnie Walker Cup he won yesterday.

ALBANY, March 26--The Legislature pressed today toward adjournment on Friday or Saturday. Heading the list of things done was the passage by the Senate of the PariMutuel Racing Bill and its immediate amendment by the Assembly Rules Committee to meet principal objections raised yesterday by Governor Lehman.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 26--At a rushed session that broke the Easter vacation, the Danish Parliament today prepared to impose new taxes of 85,000,000 kroner, which will raise the total tax burden by about one-sixth but still will fail to cover the deficit of 200,000,000 kroner in what is the biggest national budget in Danish history.

Attempts by the Board of Education to retire a 51-year-old, 275pound married teacher, in the New York City school system since 1906, who, because of her physical condition, has become a "fire hazard," have been balked by the Board of Superintendents, James Marshall, president of the education board, disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26(AP)-- The annual meeting of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company was adjourned today until 2 P.M. tomorrow, when a brisk skirmish is expected to develop over opposition of a minority group to the company's present executive management.
BERGEN, Norway, March 26-- "There is an airplane overhead," reported a seaman to the commander of a Norwegian destroyer in coastal waters today.

CHICAGO, March 26--A possibility that the Southwest might receive much needed moisture overnight and increased pressure of hedging sales against grain redeemed by farmers from the government loan kept wheat prices on the downgrade today.

STAMP collecting, the sport of kings and schoolkids ("that weakest and most puerile of manias," some one once called it), is a century old this year. ALBANY, March 27--The Senate voted today to create a legislative committee to look into the question of assessment review for real estate. Bills setting up boards of assessment review were introduced at this session, but died in committee.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Thomas E. Dewey was called "unfitted to be the Republican candidate for President" in a statement issued today by Representative George H. Tinkham, Republican, of Massachusetts. Mr. Tinkham said Mr. Dewey had made statements which evidenced "his lack of sympathy with traditional American policies."

LOS ANGELES, March 27--Wholesale violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act by most of Southern California's leading lumber, plastering, marble, and heating and ventilating contractors was charged today in four indictments returned by a special Federal grand jury.
Prime Minister Mackenzie King must feel well pleased with himself today. His Liberal Government is back in power with the most sweeping parliamentary majority in Canadian history.
A century-old dwelling of unusual type at the upper fringe of Greenwich Village has just changed hands.

BOSTON, March 27--All square with two victories apiece, the New York Rangers and Boston Bruins will resume their hockey play-off series leading to the Stanley Cup finals before another capacity crowd of more than 16,000 in the Boston Garden tomorrow night.

More than 500 men and women attended a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night to start a city-wide appeal of the New York Association for the Blind for $566,356 to be used for a new building and the expansion of services to the blind.

Both Joe Louis and Johnny Paychek concluded heavy training yesterday for their match tomorrow for the world heavyweight boxing championship at Madison Square Garden. Today the champion will engage only in load work, while the challenger will rest completely.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Income payments to individuals in February increased 6 per cent over similar payments in February, last year, to a total of $5,554,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 27--Rain today washed out a scheduled game in Tampa between the Giants and the Reds, giving Colonel Bill Terry time for reflection and an opportunity to wield the axe.

BERLIN, March 27--The National Socialist conception of war was further elucidated in a somewhat startling manner by Dr. Robert Ley, head of the Labor Front, in the newspaper Angriff today. He said war was a "blessing of God, the eternal fount from which new generations of men are born."
Several large apartment units in buildings on the East Side in the midtown section were reported yesterday as having been taken through various brokers.

Play will be resumed tonight in the national indoor polo championships, with two games at Squadron A Armory.

MOSCOW, March 27--The Soviet Union is planning big changes in the inland waterways shipping system to increase the facilities for the transport of oil.

Fifty-nine subscriptions in thirtyseven different interests have been made for the Spring Maiden Steeplechase, according to an announcement yesterday from the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Employment of currency-depreciation practices, outlawed by the Tripartite Monetary Agreement and the reciprocal trade agreements, to stimulate the export trade of belligerents to the United States will not be tolerated, Administration officials indicated today.

ALBANY, March 27--The bills strengthening the State Liquor Control Law, including one prohibiting the sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under 18 years of age, instead of 16, were passed today in the Assembly.

Mr. and Mrs. Christian Carl Randlov of Copenhagen, Denmark, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Else Kristine Randlov of 24 Central Park South, this city, to George Emlen Roosevelt Jr., son of George Emlen Roosevelt of 1,001 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, March 27--The veteran Willie Hoppe continued to make a runaway of the world threecushion billiard tournament tonight, chalking up his twelfth consecutive victory and coming within two innings of the world tournament best-game mark of twentythree innings in overwhelming Art Thurnblad, 50 to 21.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The story of a frugal Bronx woman, wife of a barber, who paid $4,395 to an alleged loan shark in futile efforts to pay up loans of about $250, after she had borrowed an original $50, was disclosed yesterday in Federal court.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 27--Yesterday's attempted revolt was definitely quelled today with the confinement of Javier Paz Campero, Gabriel Gonsalvez, Jose Tamayo and Roberto Jordan Cuellar, Leftist leaders, the first three of whom were defeated in the last elections.

ALBANY, March 27--The Assembly defeated today, by a vote of 87 to 48, the Wright bill providing for State regulation of outdoor advertising on public highways.

Owen Cattell of 40 Washington Square, assistant to the editor of Science, official weekly journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and business manager of The Science Press, died Tuesday night of pneumonia in the New York Hospital. He was 42 years old.
Tom Iannicelli, world open squash tennis champion, began his defense of his title last night with a 15-5, 15-9, 15-5 victory over H. Robert Reeve Jr. at the Shelton Club.

BERLIN, March 27--Premier Paul Reynaud's speech yesterday as well as certain utterances in the Allied press are taken in Berlin as an indication that the Allies still have not given up the idea of making any one of several neutral nations the starting point of active warfare.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Hearings which are expected to last six weeks or longer were begun today by a House Ways and Means subcommittee on the chain-store tax bill of Representative Patman, Democrat, of Texas, which is designed, according to Mr. Patman, to restrict chains to the boundaries of a single State or smaller area.
A banking syndicate headed by the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of $28,160,000 of city, of Miami, Fla., refunding bonds on an interest cost basis to the city of 3.7622 per cent.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 27 --Racing through a steady, thin rain and over a track deep in slop, O.L. Foster's Peon accounted for the Indian River Purse, a six-furlong dash at Tropical Park today.

Count it as good fortune that Gladys George, the aureate blonde, has opportunity to run through all her paces in Margery Sharp's "Lady in Waiting," which was put on in Martin Beck's house last evening. Cast as the vulgar mother of a priggish snip, the incredible George is immensely funny and likable.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 27 (AP)-- Behind the four-hit pitching of Ken Chase and Joe Haynest the Senators earned a 5-to-2 decision today over the Tigers, who had beaten them in two earlier skirmishes.

HAINES CITY, Fla., March 27-- Motoring here from their temporary Sebring training base, the Yankees today went through all the motions of impressing their importance upon their Kansas City farm hands. Marse Joe MeCarthy, indeed, put his entire front line troops on display and kept them there all day.
ALBANY, March 27--The Senate today killed the Rapp bill which would have required semi-annual inspection of all motor vehicles operating at a fee of 50 cents a car.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 27 (AP)--Captain John Matheson, one of the vanishing line of famous fishing skippers of the days of sail, died today at the age of 59.
LONDON, March 27--British press dispatches from the Western Front said tonight that five German Messerschmitt fighting planes had been shot down in three British-Nazi air battles.

Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange received yesterday permission to form affiliated corporations for their underwriting activities and for the carrying of firm positions. None will be required to incorporate.

BOSTON, March 27--Mme. Emelie Alexander Marius, former concert singer and teacher of voice, who was the first American woman to be elected to the French Academy, died yesterday at her home, 38 Hemenway Street, Back Bay. She was 86 years old.

Although improving slightly in some products, new steel business has failed to develop in sufficient volume to arrest the decline in production, which has continued almost without interruption since last November, according to Iron Age.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 27 (AP)--Three spies were sentenced to prison in the Netherlands today.

BERGEN, Norway, March 27--In the choppy, windswept waters of this beautiful mountain-enclosed harbor a score of good-sized ships rode at anchor today. Most of them had assembled here to be convoyed across the hazardous North Sea under the protection of British warships.

ST. LOUIS, March 21 (AP)--Edgar M. Queeny, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, urges investors and employes of industry to "become aggresive in refuting false statements that industry is responsible for the ills of the nation."

Despite sales of heavy native steer hides at concessions of cent, packers yesterday held firm on their quotations for light native cows, and their action gave new emphasis to the widening differential between heavy and light hides, with the lighter skins bringing premiums.

Although another severe break occurred yesterday in sterling exchange, cotton quotations in Liverpool and Bombay improved. With less Foreign selling pressure here, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied 6 to 10 points as mills called cotton and shorts covered.

Financing of $1,500,000 by Braniff Airways, Inc., a major portion of which will represent new capital borrowing, will be undertaken today with the public offering of 150,000 shares of capital stock at $10 each by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 27 (AP)-- Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell indicated today that the $5,000,000 damage suit against George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., growing out of Mr. Ball's sale of the Van Sweringen railroad empire to a financial group in New York would be heard in November.

BERLIN, Thursday, March 28--The Berlin fire department, aided by rain and snow, early today brought under control a fire that raged for two hours in a factory reported to be manufacturing small arms ammunition; but which is described officially as an electrical products plant.

WASHINGTON, March 27--A limit of $3,000,000 for political expenditures by party national committees was approved unanimously today by a House Judiciary subcommittee as an amendment to the Hatch "clean politics" bill adopted recently by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)-- Secretary Wallace objected today to a suggestion that the Farm Credit Administration be returned to independent status. He said he would consider removal of the agency from his jurisdiction a reflection on him, President Roosevelt and Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Frequency modulation broadcasting was endorsed at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission by officials and technicians of the Radio Corporation of America. They agreed with sponsors of the new system that it should have additional facilities.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The House forsook the path of economy today and tentatively added $67,450,000 to next year's appropriations for the Civilian Conservation camps and the National Youth Administration.

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 27-- Three inches of Carolina snow made Ben Hogan wait three days between his first and second rounds in the $5,000 Greensboro open golf tournament. But it didn't take a bit of the fever heat out of his game.
LONDON, March 27 (AP)--Thirtythree horses, four of them American-owned, were announced today as final acceptors for the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree on April 5.
BANGOR, Me., March 27--The Democratic State convention elected twenty delegates today to cast ten votes for a third term for President Roosevelt at the national convention.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Preliminary to probable argument of the case Friday, the Apex Hosiery Company filed with the Supreme Court today its brief asking a judgment of $711,835 from the American Federation of Hosiery Workers (C. I.O.).

WASHINGTON, March 27--The Pittman amendment to require Senate ratification of future reciprocal trade agreements with foreign nations has gained such support that Administration leaders concede it may be adopted.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 21--From early afternoon today New Zealanders streamed solemnly past the bier of Prime Minister Michael J. Savage, who lay in state in the vestibule of Parliament House.

Continued opposition to the proposed pay cut bill for New York City school employee came from school officials, labor groups and parents yesterday. Leaders of teacher organizations, both here and in Albany, were trying to ward off passage of the measure.

The anti-trust division of the Department of Justice has begun a grand jury investigation into the affairs of Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, an A.F.L. affiliate, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, March 27--Seven men were killed in an explosion aboard the French destroyer La Railleuse, according to an announcement by the Ministry of Marine today.
The Federal Water Service Corporation will file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for rearranging its capital structure, it was announced yesterday.

One English and two Netherlands liners arrived here yesterday morning from Europe with passenger lists consisting almost exclusively of German and Austrian refugees. The three ships carried 484 refugees, and a total of 620 passengers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 27-- Mayor Frank Hague's ruling that elective officials of Hudson County cannot serve more than three terms had been extended to cover the State Senatorship, and State Senatpr Edward P. Stout of Jersey City is the first to bow to the fourthterm "tradition."

IF the polls hadn't closed a few hours earlier, the first goal scored in the Toronto-Detroit hockey game the other night might have put Sylvanus Apps in the Canadian Parliament. The Greater New York Fund, which will begin its 1940 campaign on Monday, is the largest single contributor to all the major charitable organizations of the city, James G. Blaine, president of the fund, declared yesterday, in urging wider popular support for the fund.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division restored yesterday the names of State Senator John J. McNaboe and Councilman Alfred E. Smith Jr. to next Tuesday's Democratic primary ballot in the Sixteenth Congressional District.

Widespread changes in the city's junior high schools were approved yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting at 500 Park Avenue. In some instances the revisions amount to drastic reform of existing policies.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Thursday, March 28 (AP)--The household of Mrs. Madeleine Force Astor Fiermonte stated early today that she was dead.

LONDON, March 27--Ivan M. Maisky, the Russian Ambassador, called on Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, today and protested vigorously against the British detention of Russian ships in the Pacific.

OTTAWA, March 27--In this Dominion of magnificent distances and consequent changes of time, it is only the day after a general election that the result in detail normally becomes clear. In the case of such a landslide as yesterday's, however, the broad outlines are earlier plain enough.

The vacant plot 110 by 100 feet on the southeast corner of Ocean Avenue and Quentin Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Jacob Cohen from the Greater, New York Development Company and will be improved with a six-story apartment building containing forty-eight suites. The projected building will cost about $260,000. Louis M. Rogovin was the broker.

Tuesday's unexpected dividend on the common stock of the United States Steel Corporation shook the stock market out of its area of indecision yesterday, and with the turnover the largest of the year, prices rallied along a broad front.

Joseph Equi, restaurateur, has leased 6,000 square feet in the Columbia Broadcasting System Building at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-second Street, from the Madison 52d Corporation, owner of the building.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP)-- The management of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company won today a vote of confidence from stockholders of the hugh anthracite and utility concern with the election of two of its three nominees for the board of managers and the defeat of three resolutions ...
LONDON, March 27--The stock markets remained listless today, drifting downward in the absence of business. Declines, however, were minor.

PARIS, March 27--Possibly because they desire to ascertain in what direction the "increased energy" in the conduct of the war is about to manifest itself, the Germans did much prospecting today at the front both in the air and on land.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, after a two-hour conference with a labor delegation headed by John L. Lewis, chairman of the ...

MADISON, Wis., March 27--Efforts of backers of Thomas E. Dewey to gain the support of La Follette Progressives for the New Yorker's drive for Presidential convention delegates in the State received a hard blow tonight when titular leaders of the party repudiated the "Progressive Republican Club of Wisconsin."
PARIS, March 27--All Spanish refugees remaining in internment camps in the Pyrenees and the south of France will have been released from camps by the end of this month.

Paavo Nurmi, the phlegmatic Finn, treated himself to a smile yesterday. The one-time Abo Antelope peered cautiously at his watch after sending Taisto Maki through a fast time trial at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in the morning, blinked in astonishment and pronounced himself more than satisfied.

The Misses Winifred V. Wylie and Frances L. Murdock gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Miss Lynne R. Russell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Hendrick Russell, and J. Stewart Rhoades, whose marriage will take place on Saturday in the chapel of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church.

For its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night arranged a program which presented Irina Baronova in "Les Sylphides" for the first time with this company, and restored to the repertory the Russian folk ballet "Bogatyri," ...

The accumulation of manufacturers' inventories was halted in February, but the stability which had characterized new orders in January gave way to a substantial decline in February, according to preliminary index figures compiled by the division of industrial economies of the National Industrial Conference Board.

A decision as to whether to disclose at this time the details of the private financing of the projected $1,000,000 South American tour of the All-American Youth Orchestra, to be made under the direction of Leopold Stokowski this Summer, will be announced today.

PARIS, March 8--Navy blue and white costumes are Paris Spring perennials. They blossom out around Easter time, along with the chestnut trees on the Champs-Elysees, the donkey carts in the Tuileries and the toy balloons in the Luxembourg Gardens.

PARIS, March 27--The withdrawal of Ambassador Jacob Suritz at the request of the French Government has started a new demand in the press for even more drastic changes in the relations between France and the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, March 27--The Senate passed and sent to the Assembly today, without debate and by unanimous vote, two bills amending the State tax laws in order to permit consumers to deduct the 2-cent State and the 1-cent New York City cigarette sales taxes from State income tax payments.
The audience which attended the ninth and last event of the current Town Hall concerts series yesterday evening had a particular pleasure in a feature that the customary concert does not provide.

Despite the fact that the business indices which were soaring in the last quarter of 1939 have been declining, national advertisers appear to be regaining confidence rapidly and a fairly well-sustained spurt in ad expenditures is under way, agency men remarked yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Representatives of the Administration made a public explanation today before the House Military Affairs Committee of its decision to permit Great Britain and France to buy about 2,100 airplanes ordered by the American Army. They apparently won the approbation of the committee for the program.

PARIS, March 27--The Nazi Governor of the Lublin reservation for Jews in Central Poland has refused to accept new deportees from the Reich until he receives sufficient credits to solve the housing problem in the district, according to reports in Jewish circles here.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 27--Three transatlantic clippers arrived at the Pan American Air base here today from Horta, the Azores. The American and Yankee Clippers landed this morning nine minutes apart, and the Dixie came in this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The underwriting syndicate of ninety members which will offer 715,980 shares of the no-par value common stock of Indianapolis Power and Light Company was named today in an amendment to the registration statement of the issuer filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It is hard to determine just what there was in the Feinberg resolution to amend the Judiciary Article of the State Constitution which would lead to its rejection at Albany by a straight party vote. Twenty Republicans in the Senate voted for the measure, three voted against it, three abstained.
CHICAGO, March 27--Failure of expected moisture to materialize in the Southwest overnight brought in moderate buying of wheat futures in the early trading today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 27-- Princeton University is listed as a contingent legatee of the estate of the late Wilton Lloyd-Smith, New York broker, whose will was filed for probate in Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here today.

NEW CITY, N.Y., March 27-- Testimony that Assemblyman Lawrence J. Murray of Rockland County had bet heavily on horse races in 1937 and 1938, during the period he allegedly embezzled $49,102 from Miss May A.V. Dunnigan of Haverstraw, was heard today at Murray's trial in County Court here on grand larceny charges.

WASHINGTON, March 27--Senator Vandenberg and Thomas E. Dewey, candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, favor the proposed St. Lawrence seaway, they told a group of Wisconsin Republican Representatives in Congress.

The marriage of Miss Susanne Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of 12 East Eighty-sixth Street and Point Pleasant, N.J., to John Motley Lauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Lauer of Brooklyn, took place here yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

It is hard to determine just what there was in the Feinberg resolution to amend the Judiciary Article of the State Constitution which would lead to its rejection at Albany by a straight party vote. Twenty Republicans in the Senate voted for the measure, three voted against it, three abstained.

Profit-taking honeycombed the stock market yesterday and halted any possibility of an extension of the smart rise that was experienced on Wednesday, although the volume on the Stock Exchange still held above the million-share mark.

Henry L. Bogert of the brokerage firm of Eastman, Dillon Co. has leased an apartment containing ten rooms and four baths in 160 East Seventy-second Street through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 28--Eighty thousand letters destined for the United States were taken off the Pan American Airways Atlantic Clipper today at Bermuda by British censors, it was disclosed this afternoon when the flying boat arrived here.

BOSTON, March 28--Once more the New York Rangers built a onegoal margin of superiority over the Bruins in their play-off series for the right to play for the Stanley Cup. And once more that slim margin was provided by a defenseman as the Blue Shirts registered a 1-to-0 triumph over the National Hockey League champions tonight.

The strains of "The Wedding March" ushered in the fashion show held by Russeks at the luncheon hour yesterday in the Terrace and Persian Rooms of the Plaza Hotel. Gowns for brides and their attendants were presented for seven wedding hours between 11 A.M. and 8:30 P.M.

A total of sixty typical retail stories, relating unusual results from newspaper advertising, are contained in "It Sells," a brochure released yesterday by the promotion and research department of the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.
SEATTLE, March 28 (AP)--All eight seeded stars reached the quarter-finals in the women's singles of the national badminton tournament today.

The Board of Transportation conferred for two hours yesterday with representatives of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, without reaching a decision on the resolution it will adopt to define its policy after transit unification...
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 28--Skiing has gripped this historical city, which is now seeking recognition as one of America's outstanding Winter sports centers.

ALBANY, March 28--The Senate passed unanimously today and sent to the Assembly the Williamson bill to establish a Westchester County Parkway Authority with power to levy tolls on the Saw Mill River and Hutchinson River Parkways.
The Bankers Trust Company of New York purchased yesterday $1,000,000 city of Utica, N.Y., certificates of indebiedness at 0.08 per cent. The certificates, dated March 29, will mature on July 29.

There is no threat to steeplechasing in the State Racing Commission's recommendation of eightrace programs, it was stated yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman, who also gave it as his opinion that 2:30 P.M. would be the post time at Jamaica with seven races as the probable card.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28--A proposal for refinancing of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company whereby it would save $13,088,770 in twenty-five years, according to Thomas R. Crumley, president, was considered here today by the State Public Utilities Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 28--The Senate Military Affairs Committee voted, 5 to 4, today against reporting favorably the La Follette resolution to order an investigation into the sale of military planes to other powers.

Warning that it was a "gross violation" of the competitive merit system, Dr. William A. Hannig, chairman of the Board of Exami ners of the city Board of Education, yesterday denounced the Phelps-Page bill in Albany, which would establish a system of veterans' preference in teachers examinations.

WASHINGTON, March 28--As the special hearing on "frequencymodulation" before the Federal Communications Commission ended here, it became known that applications for the construction and operation of such stations had reached a total of 109, including the latest one, received today, from WMCA of New York.

Bank transactions of the major cities of the nation amounted to $4,570,564,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. New York, which was the only city to fall behind the previous year, was again responsible for the 6.7...
MADRID, March 28--Generalissimo Francisco Franco was acclaimed by thousands this morning when he arrived at his office in the Royal Palace on the first anniversary of the capture of Madrid.
Dr. Robert W. Bruere, chairman of the Maritime Labor Board, defended the agency yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Port of New York unit of the Propeller Club of the United States.

LONDON, March 28--H.G. Wells called the British Government "grossly incompetent" today and said that Prime Minister Chamberlain and the Foreign Secretary, Viscount Halifax, were "just playing about with the war."

Despite the icy condition of many streams and ponds in the State, the Spring trout stocking programs are being carried out as rapidly as possible, according to an announcement from Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne. In line with the plan inaugurated last year...

Fear that the Roosevelt Administration, despite all said to the contrary, is driving the United States toward participation in the European war was expressed yesterday by Frank E. Gannett, aspirant for the Republican nomination for President.

Nicholas Dozenberg, former roving secret agent of the Soviet Russian Army, appeared in Federal court yesterday a humbled man, pleading for a chance to rehabilitate himself as a citizen in the American tradition. His repentance came too late, however. Judge Samuel Mandelbaum sent him to prison for a year and a day for falsifying his American passport.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28-- A terrific downpour washed out the Dodger-Red Sox game today, the last contest scheduled here. It was not an electrical storm, but the rain was accompanied by thunder.

The reciprocal trade agreement program of the Roosevelt Administration, one of the best accomplishments of its seven years in office, faces a critical test today. The Senate is expected to vote on an amendment offered by Mr. Pittman which would require ratification of all future agreements of this kind by a two-thirds vote of the Senate.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 28--Thomas E. Dewey added tonight to his previous indictment of the New Deal a bitter denunciation of the Administration of WPA. He spoke before more than 20,000 Republicans who gathered at the Chicago Stadium in a cheering, shouting, carnival mood. It was the largest crowd he has addressed in his preconvention campaign for the Presidential nomination.

The 1939 pamphlet report of the United Gas Corporation and subsidiaries, made public yesterday by Joe H. Gill, president, shows a consolidated net income of $5,030,030 for the year after all expenses and charges, compared with $5,390,515 in 1938. Gross revenues were $41,552,759, against $40,772,224.

The Rossini overture to "Semiramide"; the Concerto by Benjamin, Britten, for violin and orchestra in D minor, opus 16, played for the first time here by Antonio Brosa, and Beethoven's Fifth Symphony made the program of the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 28--The House passed today the $1,021,639,700 Labor-Security Appropriation Bill after upholding on two separate record votes the unbudgeted $67,450,000 added to the measure yesterday.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 28 (AP)--The Boston Bees made extra-base hits count today as they defeated the Detroit Tigers, 3--1, in a Grapefruit League game behind the steady pitching of Jim Tobin and Bill Swift.

ALBANY, March 28--Political considerations arose today to complicate plans of the Legislature to adjourn tomorrow or Saturday. The fate in both houses of the pay-cut bill for teachers in New York City was left in uncertainty.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 28 --Five hours after her return from Easter vacation Miss Rachel Hutchinson Taylor, a freshman student from Wildwood, N.J., at Pennsylvania State College, was found slain today outside a rural school house five miles from the campus.

WASHINGTON, March 28--Senate leaders on both sides agreed tonight that the Administration would be able to defeat, by a narrow margin, the Pittman amendment to the trade-agreements resolution when it came to a vote at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

With training classes for censustakers completed, New York district offices of the Census Bureau were beginning yesterday to administer the required "oath of office"-- including an oath of secrecy--preparatory to sending the enumerators out on their doorbell-ringing duties Tuesday, Kirke D. Austin, area manager, announced.

LONDON, March 28--A slightly better tendency developed in the stock markets today with more activity in some sections. British funds were firm because of South Africa's decision to repay in cash 7,900,000 of the 5 per cent 1940-60 loan. This decision was made, it is believed, because of the demand for short-term gilt-edge securities.

CHICAGO, March 28--Total loans and discounts of Chicago's banks held nearly steady in the first three months of 1940, according to figures made public today in response to Federal and State calls for statements of condition as of last Tuesday. The Board of Superintendents of the New York City school system made public yesterday a resolution praising the late Dr. John H. Finley as "an educator of his fellow-men." The "splendid influence" of the former editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES was cited by the superintendents.

The fall of rates in what is called "free sterling" has become a major phenomenon of the international market. In January, sterling was quoted on Wall Street at $4. Falling to $3.92 at the end of February, it gave way rapidly in March.

Extension of the Federal food stamp program to needy families in this city moved a step closer last night with the disclosure that Mayor La Guardia had asked Welfare Commsisioner William Hodson to prepare plans for an experiment in the use of stamps in one borough.
The profits of the banking syndicate that underwrote the rise of the masquerading F. Donald Coster were indicated yesterday by evidence in the McKesson Robbins fraud trial in Federal court.

Everybody who has been waiting for strawberries to come down, before indulging in them for a Spring dessert, can have a fling at them this week. The price has tumbled to 15 cents a pint and their quality could hardly be better.

Ports that have not been made in years were included last night in the itinerary of the New York Yacht Club cruise announced by Commodore E. Townsend Irvin at that organization's second general meeting, held in its clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Marked changes in policy are indicated for the new firm of Merrill Lynch, E.A. Pierce Cassatt, which is to commence operations on Monday, according to statements yesterday by Charles E. Merrill and E.A. Pierce, the two senior partners.
In the thirty-five years since its establishment, the Milbank Memorial Fund has expended $11,550,093 for grants and projects of a philanthropic nature, the fund's annual report disclosed yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 28--The Spring session of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) opens tomorrow and the delegates are already pouring into this capital from all parts of the Soviet Union.

A field of twelve teams will start action today in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association's forty-seventh annual championship tournament at the N.Y.U. School of Education gymnasium.

Totaling $45,018,000, engineering construction awards this week are 14 per cent lower than last week and 24 per cent below the volume for the corresponding week of 1939, according to The Engineering News-Record.
Rockefeller Center, vast midtown commercial and amusement project conceived a little more than a decade ago and carried forward during the depression at a cost of $100,000,000, is completed.

Bert Fish, who has been United States Minister to Egypt since the beginning of the present Administration in 1933, came back home for a holiday yesterday with a new title and a new experience, both without precedent in American diplomatic annals.
SEBRING, Fla., March 28--The Yankees spent another afternoon sampling the wares of their farm hands today, but, if there was any fun in it, not much of it was enjoyed by the world champions.

A Yorkville property that had been in the family of the late Jacob Ruppert, brewer and owner of the New York Yankees, passed to new hands yesterday when brokers announced the sale of the two fivestory apartment houses at 204 and 206 East Eighty-fourth Street, 100 feet east of Third Avenue.

BERLIN, March 28--The increased activity of the British sea force in Norwegian waters is being followed by the German Admiralty with considerable but, allegedly, not apprehensive interest--for the time being.

Joe Louis, most active champion in the history of his division, will lay his heavyweight championship on the line again tonight at Madison Square Garden, where he will meet Johnny Paychek of Des Moines, Iowa, in a battle scheduled for fifteen rounds.
City College captured the first tournament of the newly organized Eastern Intercollegiate Chess Association, which was completed yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club.

ALBANY, March 28--The Assembly passed and sent to Governor Lehman today the Young-Wadsworth bill setting up a system of merit rating for employers in the payment of contributions to the Unemployment Insurance Fund. Supporters of the measure estimated that it would save employers $50,000,000 annually.
Hitler wanted something when he hurried to the Brenner to meet Mussolini: this much we know. Exactly what he wanted, or what response he received, we do not yet know.

SHANGHAI, March 28--The revelation by THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 5 of the extent of German penetration and activity in Yunnan Province has so excited French authorities in Indo-China that several European and American official observers are gathering at Hanoi and Haiphong to watch developments.
A construction project of considerable significance to the New York building industry will be started today at South Grand Avenue and Prospect Street, in Baldwin, L.I.

The Municipal Art Society of New York is sponsoring a movement to erect on a spur of the Palisades known as King's Bluff, near Weehawken and above the New Jersey entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel, a gigantic bronze head of Lincoln by the late George Grey Barnard, famous American sculptor.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net profit of $5,218,259 in 1939, the highest in its history, Guy W. Vaughan, president, reported yesterday. The net compared with $3,598,739 earned in 1938, a gain of 45 per cent. Net profit in 1937 was $1,983,609.

Establishing itself as a real threat in the national junior indoor polo championship, the 124th Field Artillery of Chicago beat Squadron A, 23 to 7, at the latter's armory last night and gained the right to meet Ridgewood in the final round tomorrow night.

A plot to kill a key witness in the investigation into the Brooklyn murder ring was balked last Sunday night by the opportune arrival of detectives from his office, District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn charged yesterday as he pressed grand jury proceedings against members of the ring.
With his 1940 budget virtually completed, Mayor La Guardia made a final appeal yesterday to the Legislature to restore $5,000,000 in city revenues before it adjourns.
A sharp rally featured the freemarket quotation of the pound sterling here yesterday and carried the rate up 11 cents on the day to $3.60. This compared with a net loss on Wednesday of 8 cents.

Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, urged the liberalization of the Federal old-age pension and insurance programs in two ways last night. He advocated larger Federal aid to poor States to establish a nation-wide minimum pension and wider coverage for old-age insurance by including the millions of self-employed.

A revival of private building through rehabilitation of blighted areas along neighborhood unit lines was urged yesterday by representatives of banking, building and planning interests at a conference in the Great Hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 28 --The Rev. Dr. Richard L. Swain, retired clergyman, lecturer and author, died here today at the home of his oldest son, Judge Richard S. Swain, after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.

Termination of the Russian invasion of Finland has by no means checked the generosity of Americans wishing to show their sympathy with both combatant and civilian victims of the conflict, and it was announced yesterday that contributions to the Finnish Relief Fund, Inc., had passed the $3,000,000 mark.

Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and five associations of electrical and plumbing contractors were accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of maintaining a virtual monopoly of a phase of the electrical industry in New York City for their mutual benefit.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 28--Funeral services for Harry C. Adler, who for thirty-two years was general manager of The Chattanooga Times, will be held here tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock in the Julius and Bertha Ochs Memorial Temple. Rabbi Abraham Feinstein will officiate.

TRENTON, March 28--Drafted by four Republican Senators, at $27,000,000 State financing program was laid today before a committee of Assembly Republicans and it was agreed to prepare for introduction a series of eleven bills to make the plan effective.

Police of New York and Paterson, N.J., yesterday were holding two men, one as a vagrant in bail of $25,000 and the other as a disorderly person without bail, while they tried to find an explanation for 125 pounds of dynamite found on the Passaic River bank last Nov. 30.

ROME, March 28--While thirty trimotored bombers roared overhead, Premier Mussolini today personally awarded 687 medals for bravery to pilots who had distinguished themselves in the Ethiopian and Spanish wars. Santelmann, son of a former leader.

LONDON, March 28--A family as well as a military crisis among the large Irish colony here has been considerably eased by a new "sympathetic" arrangement between the British Government and the De Valera regime that softens the impact of the British conscription laws on citizens of the republic.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 28--The United States replaced Great Britain as the chief source of Argentina's import trade in the first two months of this year, supplying 27.1 per cent of the total, compared to Britain's 20.9 per cent, according to the monthly report of the National Statistical Bureau published today.

IF you read at the average pace it would take you about twenty-nine hours to go through this morning's paper thoroughly. Somewhere between 2,500 and 3,500 people devoted yesterday to getting it out. It contains as many words as five or six novels, not to mention all the material that will soon or later turn up again in a great many books.

The newest journal in town, if you haven't already come upon it, is The New York Daily Mail. It prints only stale news, except for the robust black headlines. These are done to your order, three inches high, in a space under the masthead.

DETROIT, March 28 (AP)--Olympia Arena was turned into a battleground of fists and sticks tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs charged into the Stanley Cup play-off finals by beating the Red Wings, 3 to 1.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 28-- The Most Rev. Moses Elias Kiley was enthroned today as the sixth Archbishop of Milwaukee in the Church of the Gesu by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani of Washington, D.C., Papal Delegate to the United States.

With the expiration yesterday of the time within which distillers were told by organized bar and grill owners to "clean up the local market," spokesmen for the tavern keepers said last night that they were well satisfied with the progress made.

OLMSTEDVILLE, N.Y., March 28 (AP)--Wesley Barnes, who in 1885 sponsored a bill in New York's Assembly which created the State Forest Commission, forerunner of the Conservation Department, died today in his home here at the age of 98.

ALBANY, March 28--The State will not accept the seventy-one acres of Greystone, the Yonkers estate left to it by Samuel Untermyer, it was decided today at a conference in which Governor Lehman participated. The lawyer stipulated in his will that the State must accept the gift within six months after his death.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 28--A British bomber flying over the Netherlands was attacked and forced down near Rotterdam by two Netherland pursuit ships at 6:15 o'clock this morning.

TOKYO, March 28--Sir Robert Craigie, British Ambassador to Tokyo, told a distinguished gathering of Japanese and Britons here today that their two countries were "ultimately striving for the same objective--namely, lasting peace and the preservation of our institutions from extraneous and subversive influences."

Of chief interest in the doings of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in its two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday were the restoration to the repertory of "Coppelia" at the matinee and the first appearance of Irina Baronova in "Swan Lake" in the evening.

WASHINGTON, March 28--The Dies Committee investigating unAmerican activities voted unanimously today to cite George Powers, Russian-born secretary of the Communist party in Western Pennsylvania, for contempt of the House.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 28 --William Libbey Sexton, oldest alumnus of Princeton University and sole survivor of the class of 1863, died tonight at his home here, 38 Winans Street. He was 95 years old, and had been bedridden for more than a year as a result of a hip injury.
OTTAWA, March 28--The Canadian Cabinet held its first meeting since the general election this evening, sitting for three hours.

LONDON, Friday, March 29--A German Heinkel raider, diving to escape three British Hurricane fighters piloted by sergeants, went through thick clouds only to meet a burst of bullets from another British squadron and fall to the sea in flames.

WASHINGTON, March 28--Senator Connally angrily retorted today to Thomas E. Dewey's assertion last night that the Roosevelt Administration could not be relied upon to keep this country out of war. The Texan declared that "we have kept out of war without any assistance from Mr. Dewey."

LOS ANGELES, March 28 (AP)-- Dr. Bertrand Russell, whose appointment to the faculty of City College in New York is being contested in the courts, today joined his wife in a statement denying that he ever conducted a nudist camp or practiced nudity, or "went in" for salacious poetry.

BOSTON, March 28 (AP)--William J. Bingham, Harvard's athletic director, criticized President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago tonight for taking the stand that football "has no place in a college program" instead of helping to curb the evils in the sport.

SHANGHAI, March 28--With the Japanese-sponsored regime headed by Wang Ching-wei scheduled to be inaugurated at Nanking on Saturday, Shanghai was buzzing tonight with the wildest rumors and conjectures, which received added circulation and credence because it was definitely known that this week at least fourteen apparently empty Japanese transports had gathered outside Woosung and steamed up the Yangtze to undisclosed destinations.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

ALBANY, March 28--The MoffatCoudert bill, to take control over the rate of fare on New York City's unified subway system from the hands of the Legislature and give this power instead to the city's Board of Estimate, was passed today by the Senate.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 28--Albert R. Brand, research associate in the Departments of Ornithology at Cornell University and the American Museum of Natural History, New York, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

ROME, March 28--Pope Pius greeted Count Paul Teleki, the Hungarian Premier, this morning in the longest private audience of his pontificate, which was testimony both to his keen interest in the Danubian and Balkan situations and the critical state that affairs there have reached.

The National Dairy Products Corporation, through Goldman, Sachs Co., fiscal agents, today will notify holders of its 3 per cent debentures due in 1951, that it will redeem on May 1 at 100 and accrued interest $938,000 of these debentures which have been drawn.

LOUIS, March 28 (AP)--The board of directors and executive committee of the St. Louis Shoe Manufacturers' Association made tentative plans today for the filing of a suit contesting the recent order of Philip B. Fleming, wage and hour administrator, establishing a minimum wage of 35 cents an hour for shoe workers.

Gibson, board chairman of the Fair Corporation, pronounced the ground "officially broken" for the two homes in which "typical American families" will dwell during the 1940 exposition season.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28-- With the statement that he believed business men had been too much depressed by "boom talk," A.W.R. Robertson, chairman of the board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said today that he was of the opinion that "the worst is over."

Daley, president of Otis Co., Cleveland, has criticized the character of the association's reply of March 18 to the Securities and Exchange Commission's questionnaire on the matter of "arms-length bargaining."

LONDON, March 29 (AP)--Relations between Great Britain and Russia became increasingly shaky tonight as the British handed over to their French ally two Soviet freighters and got ready to round up German ships attempting to dash from the Netherland East Indies to Vladivostok.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 29 --Soviet Russia is to rebuild the famous Mannerheim Line into a "Stalin Line" and double its size and strength, it was learned today from reliable sources.

The 141st session of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church will be held beginning Thursday at 11 A.M. and continuing through Monday, April 8, in the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. Presiding will be Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area.

SINGAPORE, March 29--The Batavia correspondent of The Straits Times here reports signs that German vessels lying in Netherland Indies ports are preparing for a sudden departure. He adds that several of the ships are being loaded with coal and cargo, extra crews being engaged, the ships being painted gray with black funnels and their names removed.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29--Newark was ordered today by the State Local Government Commissioner, Walter R. Darby, to increase the tax levy in the proposed 1940 budget from $36,343,698 to $40,914,225, which would raise the present tentative tax rate from $4.92 to $5.42 for each 100 of assessed valuation.

WASHINGTON, March 29--A German White Book issued today concerning alleged American machinations for war was branded by President Roosevelt as sheer propaganda.

TAMPA, Fla., March 29 (AP)-- Paced by Big Hank Greenberg, who scored twice in an eight-run inning, the Tigers walloped the Reds, 10 to 8, today. Greenberg hit safely four times, his double and homer featuring the seventh round.

The flotation of $28,160,000 of refunding bonds by Miami, Fla., was the feature of the market for new issues this week and lifted the total for the period to $47,182,000, the largest in three weeks. Last week only $13,516,444 in new bonds was placed on the market. A year ago this week $76,974,000 was offered to the public.

Having decided to appeal to men with incomes above the mass level, the General Cigar Company will concentrate its Spring advertising campaign for Robt. Burns cigars in newspapers. The size and continuity of copy have been sharply expanded over those in recent years, the ruling principle of the campaign being to face the 10-cent cigar smoker with larger display and to impress him with greater lasting effect.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, author of the National Health Bill now pending before Congress, revealed last night that the bill was being redrafted to embody a number of suggestions made by various interested organizations, including the American Medical Association.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 29--Members of a jury made news here today, after several audibly expressed dissatisfaction with the verdict of a judge, one going so far as to call it "rotten."

Another murder indictment in Brooklyn, naming three men and an impending one in the Bronx that will name at least two more, yesterday marked the progress of the investigation into the murder syndicate that centered in Brooklyn's Brownsville section.

CHICAGO, March 29 (AP)--Willie Hoppe of New York breezed through Tiff Denton of Kansas City, 50 to 45, in thirty-five innings tonight for his fourteenth consecutive victory in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament.

Frederick L. Cranford, subway contractor, chairman of the Long Island Ten-Year Plan Committee and long a Brooklyn civic leader, died of pneumonia early yesterday at his home, 479 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 71.

The attention paid to the United States Steel Corporation's unexpected declaration, last Tuesday, of 1 per cent dividend on its common stock was occasioned by the fact that steel trade activity, and by inference the profits of steel-making companies, are apt to reflect the general industrial trend.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 29--Miss Grace Hinsdale Jones, daughter of Mrs. Edgar George Jones of this city, was married here this afternoon to Earle Burr Henley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henley of Oakland, Calif., in Sage Chapel of Cornell University. The Rev. K.E. Charles of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Counsel for members of Jehovah's Witnesses was sharply rebuked today by Chief Justice Hughes, who interrupted argument to make a warm defense of the rights of individuals to worship as they pleased, and to enjoy the privacy of their homes without intrusion by proselyting members of other sects.
Houses in Manhattan and the Bronx passed the new control in deals reported yesterday.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 29--While State motor police searched today for the weapons with which Rachel Taylor, Pennsylvania State College freshman, was slain near the campus yesterday morning, a 33-year-old heating contractor of this town was taken into custody in Philadelphia for questioning.

Starano Miele, 60 years old, an assistant corporation counsel and Supreme Venerable of the Sons of Italy, was arrested yesterday in District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office on the accusation made by an apartment house handyman that since 1929 the official had retained $5,000 to $7,000 of savings the workman had entrusted to Mr. Miele to purchase Italian Government consolidated bonds.

NANKING, China, Saturday, March 30 (AP)--An "All-China" Japanese-sponsored regime headed by former Chinese Premier Wang Ching-wei was proclaimed here today at brief ceremonies without untoward incident. Japan was the only foreign country represented.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Roundlot volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on March 9 was 3,916,120 shares, compared with 3,296,040 in the preceding week, a gain of 620,080, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 29--With a simple funeral service, Harry C. Adler, general manager of The Chattanooga Times for thirty-two years until he retired in 1931, was laid to rest here this afternoon in the family mausoleum. Rabbi Abraham Feinstein conducted the ceremonies at the Julius and Bertha ...

Like many before him who had tried and failed, Johnny Paychek did not remember what had happened to him in the ring last night. Obviously disappointed and angry at himself for his poor showing, the Des Moines challenger sat on the table in his dressing room and listened to Benny Leonard, his trainer, describe what had occurred.

ALBANY, March 29--Both houses of the Legislature joined today in sending to the Governor the Mitchell-Nunan Housing Bill designed to speed slum-clearance projects through the aid of private capital. Legislation of this type was urged by Governor Lehman in his annual message.

The New York Central Railroad earned a net income after all charges in the first two months of this year, according to Washington advices quoting F.E. Williamson, president. He said storms and cold had cost the railroad $1,500,000 in January and February and that trains had been stopped by snow ...

Responding yesterday to an emergency message from Mayor La Guardia, the City Council asked the Legislature to grant a forty-eighthour extension for submission of the Mayor's executive budget to the Board of Estimate.

We don't know about you, but we're going to make something of an effort to get up to try the Tabusintac this Spring, just to see what it is like to take a salmon every other cast. Where is it? Well, its a bit beyond the Beaverkill-- about 500 miles beyond it, to be exact.

PIERRE PART, La., March 29 (AP)--High winds accompanied by a driving rain swept through here at 11 o'clock this morning, leaving four known dead, two missing and thirty-five injured, while many others are believed to be still buried in debris of the devastated fishing village.

WASHINGTON, March 29--President Roosevelt refused today to endorse a $1,000,000,000 relief appropriation as adequate for the coming fiscal year and indicated that if a larger amount was not provided the new Congress in January would face a request to increase the fund.

Elated that they shattered the Boston ice jinx without any adverse effects, the Rangers returned to New York yesterday determined to continue their winning streak and terminate their Stanley Cup hockey semi-final play-off series with the Bruins in Madison Square Garden tonight.

A lease on an apartment consisting of ten rooms and four baths in the building at 888 Park Avenue taken by Mrs. Eleanor S. Adler through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., featured the contracts for residential quarters reported by brokers yesterday.

The annual report of the North American Rayon Corporation for 1939, announced yesterday, disclosed a net profit of $2,010,252 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Army's saber team made a strong bid for honors in the forty-seventh annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships by qualifying all three of its entrants in the semi-finals at the N.Y.U. School of Education gymnasium last night.

PARIS, March 5--Paris is just as partial to plaids as ever. Orders from G.H.Q. may force reluctant Scots to abandon their kilts, but Parisiennes will continue to swirl them on many occasions, for town as well as sports.

ALBANY, March 29--Broad and unrestricted opportunities for success exist for those who have the vision, the equipment, the industry and the courage to seize them, Governor Lehman declared tonight in a radio address, delivered at the Executive Mansion.

CLEVELAND, March 29--A Federal grand jury, striking on a nation-wide scale, indicted 102 companies, trade associations, unions and individuals here today on charges that they violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by maintaining an "uneconomical marketing system."
PARIS, March 29 (AP)--A division of Scottish Highlanders was disclosed today in military dispatches to have taken over another sector of the Western Front, relieving French soldiers.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 29--Ski fever was running high in this picturesque Utah capital city tonight in anticipation of the official Federation Internationale de Ski downhill and slalom competition tomorrow and Sunday on the towering slopes of the Wasatch Mountain, east of here.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The House approved today a resolution bringing a contempt citation against James H. Dolsen, Pittsburgh Communist, for refusal to answer questions of the Dies committee investigating un-American activities. With almost no date the House acted by voice vote.

Miss Elizabeth Kennard Abbe of Ridgefield, Conn., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Abbe of Brooklyn, was married to Frederick R. Lack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lack of Summit, N.J., yesterday noon in the home of the bridegroom at 57 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn.

HALIFAX, March 29--Into the trickle of little tragedies that sadden Canadian homes as the men of the air force overseas get into action against the empire's enemies and news of their exploits comes back, there intruded today a larger calamity close at hand which might have occurred in peacetime.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., March 29--John T. Rainier, pioneer automobile manufacturer whose Rainier cars were famous racers early in the century, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

The National Sculpture Society has presented to Anna Hyatt Huntington, noted American sculptor, a special medal of honor inscribed and dedicated to her from her confreres in testimony of their appreciation of her achievements as a sculptor and her unfailing interest in and support of her fellow-sculptors.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29-- Lippy Leo Durocher entrained his Dodgers tonight and headed northward with his own mind and several others still troubled by uncertainties.

WASHINGTON, March 29--By a margin of three votes the Senate rejected today the Pittman amendment to the reciprocal trade agreements program which would have required all future agreements to be submitted to the Senate for ratification. The amendment was beaten by a roll call vote of 44 to 41.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29-- Lewis Shelton Welch, founder of The Yale Alumni Weekly and director of many graduate movements on behalf of Yale University, died today at his residence here of a heart ailment from which he had suffered for several years. His age was 72.

William A. Brady, Broadway producer, charged yesterday that "the decline of the American theatre" could be traced to the dramatists because they are not writing plays and their organization, the Dramatists Guild, will not cooperate in any plan to advance the theatre.

MILWAUKEE, March 29--Thomas E. Dewey carried his campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination into Wisconsin today, attacking the New Deal as an administration with "a vested interest in continued unemployment" and opposed to national recovery.

LONDON, March 29--Within the last forty-eight hours the war has entered a new phase, with the Allies fighting at last with their gloves off. A decision has been taken by the French and British to use their economic and naval superiority over Germany to attempt to strangle the Reich, end the stalemate on the Western Front and recover the initiative in this war.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The American Bemberg Corporation of New York filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today regarding plans to raise $1,300,000 through the sale of its Class B common and ordinary common stock to its outstanding stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)-- The State Department disclosed today that a Mexican federal court had granted temporary injunctions against expropriation by the Mexican Government of two tracts of land owned by North American chicle-producing companies.

Since the campaign to oust mentally and physically unfit teachers started last September, the Board of Education has caused the retirement of nearly 500 school employes in New York City, it was reported yesterday. This number includes teachers retired for disability as well as for length of service or age. More than 100 teachers were retired for disability.

ALBANY, March 29--Creation of a joint legislative subcommittee to make an investigation of New York City's education system, particularly in regard to alleged subversive activities in the schools, was unanimously voted today by both houses of the Legislature.

THERE are three short novels in Kay Boyle's new book,* three very good short novels, written with all her stinging felicity of expression, and decidedly a part of the best work she has ever done.
