Charles Y. Freeman, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, announced yesterday that approximately $100,000,000 will be spent by the utility system for new construction and expansion purposes in the next three years.

Firms engaged in the various branches of advertising and publicity were prominent in the business leasing activity reported yesterday when several such organizations whose main offices are out of town took new quarters or enlarged those now occupied.

As part of its procedure to determine whether one teacher in the New York City school system is, as had been charged, a "fire hazard," officials of the Board of Education conducted a special, unexpected pupil fire drill--and then reported that the 275-pound, 51-year-old, fifth-grade instructor really was an obstacle.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 2 --In a dual move to satisfy export demands, chiefly from Germany, and to keep 1940 farm production normal, Rumania announced today that 4,000,000 of her youth would be drafted into a vast agricultural army.
Apartment, taxpayer and private residential properties figured in the realty sales reported in the Bronx yesterday.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 2-- William Talmadge Kaufman, a member of the former New York banking firm of Harvey Fisk Sons, died today at his home, 531 West Seventh Street, where he had been an invalid for twelve years. He was in his eighty-fourth year.

WASHINGTON, April 2--General John. J. Pershing, in a formal statement issued today through the War Department, said that the Women World War Veterans, Inc., of New York had been using his name in an unauthorized manner.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 2-- John P. Nicholson, track coach at Notre Dame University, who was largely responsible for the development of many championship teams throughout the United States and Canada, died of heart disease here early tonight.

Additional bank statements showing condition as of the and of March were made public yesterday. In most instances the summaries indicated new high records in total deposits and in total resources of the reporting institutions.

Manhattan properties which recently have undergone remodeling or are to be renovated by the purchasers figured largely in the city realty trading yesterday. A number are located along the East Side and two are in the vicinity of the East Harlem housing project of the New York City Housing Authority.

Michigan, with its nineteen electoral votes, is leaning to the Republicans at this time, the surveys of the American Institute of Public Opinion indicate, according to Dr. George Gallup, its director. He declares:

Net profit of the May Department Stores Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries amounted to $4,402,894 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the annual report for the year ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday.

A consolidated net profit of $4,893,590 in 1939 was reported yesterday by the International Paper and Power Company after all deductions. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements for the year, to 14 cents a share on 1,823,269 shares of common stock.
Members and employes of Newman Bros. Worms will hold their annual dinner dance on Saturday in the Franklin Towers Hotel.

Details of the Farbstein bill, providing drastic price control in the distribution of liquor in this State, were cheered by 800 package store owners of the metropolitan area at a mass meeting held at the Hotel Astor yesterday to hear a report ...

ATLANTA, April 2--The Dodgers were not a little embarrassed today when they found themselves coming to bat in the eighth inning trailing the Atlanta Crackers by seven runs. Then Brooklyn made five in the eighth, tied the score in the ninth and won in the tenth, 10--9.

KUNMING, China, April 2--Full resumption of traffic on the French-owned railway between Indo-China and Yunnan Province, China's most important transport connection with the outside world, will be effected in a few days, authoritative Chinese and French sources here in the Yunnan capital say.

Criticism of advertising as a technique of selling is as foolish as criticism of a labor-saving device in production, Dr. J. Frederic Dewhurst, economist of the Twentieth Century Fund, declared yesterday ...

WASHINGTON, April 2--Scant heed will be paid by the Administration to Congressional or other demands that Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles discuss outside the White House his recent tour of belligerent European capitals or that Ambassador William C. ...
Maxie Berger of Montreal won an eight-round decision from Johnny Rohrig, Clifton, N.J., southpaw, in the feature bout at Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Berger weighed 141, Rohrig 139.

George J. Lyons of the New York Telephone Company, chairman of the employe gifts' committee, announced yesterday that more than 1,250,000 employes of 6,000 companies had been organized in support of the 1940 drive of the Greater New York Fund.

WASHINGTON, April 2--The amended plan for reorganization of the San Francisco Bay Toll Bridge Company, which owns and operates the San Mateo-Hayward toll bridge across San Francisco Bay, was condemned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as presenting "a serious danger to the investing public."

The most elaborate and controversial nose-counting in the history of the United States got under way yesterday morning, when more than 120,000 enumerators, including 8,300 in the city of New York, began the decennial census, required by the Federal Constitution.

The Pan American Airways transatlantic flying boat Yankee Clipper, which left the La Guardia Field marine terminal at 3:04 P.M. last Sunday, officially inaugurating seaplane operations at the new municipal airport, established a new record for the eastbound flight to Lisbon, Portugal, according, to announcement yesterday by Pan American officials.

Housing authorities of sixteen localities awarded yesterday a total of $19,857,000 of temporary loan notes, of which a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company received the award of $17,635,000 at 0.44 per cent, plus ...

LONDON, April 2--The stock markets today continued mostly cheerful. In some sections there was a small increase in business but this was not general as many operators appeared to be holding off until after Prime Minister Chamberlain's speech which came too late to affect the markets.

Drastic Allied economic warfare through trade pacts limiting neutrals' exports to Germany and through widespread buying to keep materials from the Reich was announced yesterday by Prime Minister Chamberlain, ...

Elisha H. Waterman, grandson of the founder of the L.E. Waterman Company, fountain pen maker, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court charging a brother, an uncle, a cousin and other officials of the company with mismanaging and wasting its assets.
KANSAS CITY, April 2 (AP)--John B. Gage, Fusionist, was elected Kansas City's Mayor tonight over the Democratic candidate, Flavel Robertson, by a majority expected to run over 20,000 votes.
Several hundred members of society thronged the main ballroom of the Plaza last night for the second and last of the Yorkville Dinner Dances of this season.

Supporters of Vice President John N. Garner for the Democratic nomination for President lost their "key" contest for the election of delegates to the Democratic National Convention in yesterday's primary election.

At least one elementary truth about the war is re-established this morning with the first complete publication in this country of the French Yellow Book, the official selection of the diplomatic reports that poured into Paris, and into French Embassies, during the pre-war period. The documents do not, of course, cover all the ground; and it is a pity, ...

With the immensely popular exhibition of Italian Masters now it its final week, the Museum of Modern Art opened yesterday afternoon to members and guests a diverse series of new shows, all of which may be visited by the public beginning today.

Elizabeth Cody, 24-year-old nurse, was killed yesterday afternoon when she was struck by a careening stolen automobile as she walked on the sidewalk on the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Ninetysixth Street. Three other persons were hurt in the accident involving two care.
Leonide Massine's beautiful ballet "St. Francis" had its only scheduled performance in the Spring season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

H.A. Baker, president of the American Can Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting that sales thus far in 1940 have amounted to about $5,000,000 more than for the like period of 1939 on a comparable basis, but pointed out that ...

According to Department of Health statistics the city's tuberculosis death rate in 1939 was 50.3 per 100,000 inhabitants--a decrease of less than 2 per cent compared with the rate of 51.2 for 1938. The average decline for the country as a whole was twice as great.

According to a couple of telephone calls received yesterday the pseudopleuronectes (flounder to you) has definitely emerged from the ooze of Great South Bay and is showing a definite interest in the baits offered by those anglers who just can't wait any longer.
ROME, April 2--The Italian Cabinet this morning approved a bill providing for civil mobilization in war time that will include not only men and women but also children of both sexes from 13 years up.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)--The Supreme Court took under consideration today the question whether a labor union which engaged in a sit-down strike is liable for damages under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act. A final decision is expected in a few weeks.

LONDON, April 2 (AP)--The Admiralty today announced the interception and scuttling "in northern waters" of the 4,007-ton German freighter Mimi Horn, which recently left the Netherland West Indies island of Curacao. The ship was set afire by her crew, the announcement said.
In a budget which he says was "conceived in despair" and "developed in agony" Mayor La Guardia has achieved the feat of a slight reduction in the city's proposed outgo for next year.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 2 (AP)-- The Tigers ended they stay in Florida today by winning a pitcher's battle with the Senators, 4 to 2.

LONDON, April 2--Increased British competition with United States trade interests in Central and South America is expected to result from a decision taken today to extend the bid for world markets to Latin America.
The sharpest break since January in spot and future prices of raw silk in the markets here developed yesterday, after Japanese Bourses had dropped 71 to 86 yen.

Faced with the greatest crisis in their history, Jews must look to their religious principles "to build inner and outer defenses" against anti-Semitism, leaders of American Jews emphasized at a dinner meeting last night of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
With the census's controversial income questions passing the acid test in thousands of homes, Dr. Robert E. Chaddock, chairman of the Census Advisory Committee, ...

WASHINGTON, April 2--Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission would invite representatives of the National Association of Security Dealers, Inc., to discuss possible changes in the present rule on "arms'-length bargaining."

TOKYO, Thursday, April 4 (AP)-- A spokesman for the Japanese Admiralty issued a warning to the British Navy today not to institute a close-range blockade of the Russian port of Vladivostok by saying that any "illegal" activity would compel the Japanese Navy to "take action."

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3--Ralph Norton, president of the Acme Steel Company, and Mrs. Norton, for many years Winter residents, have announced their gift of a $500,000 art gallery and school to this community, to be constructed during the Summer and Fall.

Reporting a consolidated net profit of $21,537,577 for 1939 after all deductions, equal to $8.55 a share on 2,476,013 no par common shares, the Eastman Kodak Company has forwarded to stockholders a proxy statement for the annual meeting at Jersey City on April 30 which will modernize and broaden the present certificate of incoporation.

WAYCROSS, Ga., April 3--The shoe was on the other foot today as the Giants and the Indians carried their exhibition battle into this section of Georgia. Smarting under two straight reverses at the hands of National League pitchers since hitting the open road, Ossie Vitt's ...
Fordham opened its home season at Fordham Field yesterday with a 14-1 rout of St. Peter's of Jersey City. With three sophomore right- ...

Japan has not been allowed many days of enjoyment over the effusive speech which was made by the British Ambassador, Sir Robert Craigie. It was premature for Tokyo to rejoice or for China's friends to worry.

Many high-paying administrative positions in the New York City school system, unfilled by the Board of Education during last year, were dropped by Mayor La Guardia, an analysis of the line-by-line executive budget disclosed yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3-- Mrs. Edward Howland Graham entertained with a luncheon at the Bath and Tennis Club today for Mrs. J. Terry West, Mrs. Marion Eppley, Mrs. Dorsey Cullen, Mrs. John Robert Bryden, Mrs. R. Jay Flick, Mrs. John H. Morice, Mrs. W. McMaster Mills and Mrs. T. Preston Davis.
Pennsylvania Military College and Princeton will meet tomorrow night to decide the indoor intercollegiate polo championship.
STATESVILLE, N.C., April 3 (AP)--The Reds evened their series with the Red Sox at two games each today by gaining a 13-to-7 victory in a carnival of runs, hits and errors.

BERLIN, April 3--An elaborate old-age pension plan for Germany, the working out of which Chancellor Hitler entrusted to Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, on the occasion of the latter's fiftieth birthday Feb. 15, seemingly has been shelved for the present.

The Black Diamond Line, one of the American steamship companies forced to withdraw its tonnage from the North Atlantic as a result of American neutrality legislation, has been doing so well in its old trade with chartered foreign tonnage that a quarterly bonus has been granted by the board to the shore and terminal staffs, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Securities registered under the Securities Act which became fully effective in February were in the gross amount of $247,002,000, of which $231,314,000 was proposed, for sale by issuers, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The latter figure compared with only $102,375,000 for January, 1940, and $16,360,000 for February, 1939.

NEWTON, Mass., April 3 (UP)-- Dr. John Lovett Morse, twice head of the American Pediatric Society and one of the nation's leading authorities on children's diseases, died at his home today. He was 74 years old.
LONDON, April 3--Ronald H. Cross, Minister of Economic Warfare, broadcasting to the nation said tonight that the British blockade is slowly isolating Germany, and he added:

A check among distillers yesterday indicated that no other producers have submitted resignations to the Distilled Spirits. Institute or have any plans at present for following the Schenley Distillers Products Corporation in withdrawing from the organization.

After twenty seven years of service, John D. Rockefeller Jr. withdrew as chairman and member of the board of trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation yesterday under a provision of the by-laws fixing the retirement age at 65 for officers and trustees. Last year Mr. Rockefeller quit his post in the General Education Board, also established by his father.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 --There is little doubt in the Balkans tonight that this war has entered a new phase and there is a coincidental anxiety that the tightening of Great Britain's economic blockade of Germany may eventually bring with it not only the threat of a showdown in this area but grave consequences to the internal industrial structure.

The jewelry business of E.M. Gattle Co., which has been on Fifth Avenue for forty of the fiftyseven years of its existence, will have new quarters on May 1 as the result of a lease nade yesterday in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel. The concern leased the store at 781 Fifth Avenue in the hotel through Frederick Fox Co., brokers.

Jeremiah Milbank holds 11,900 shares of Southern Railway common stock and through a holding company has a beneficial interest of 75 per cent in 25,000 additional shares, the notice of the annual meeting to be held on May 21 issued yesterday discloses.

The $2,500,000,000 Electric Bond and Share Company utilities system placed yesterday the problem of geographic integration squarely before the Securities and Exchange Commission and, in effect, demanded clarification of certain matters before it pertaining to the corporate relationship of the Bond and Share group before any attempt is made to apply the integration provisions of Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, April 3--A Senate appropriations subcommittee, despite President Roosevelt's admonition against such increases, today added $25,000,000 for rivers and harbors and flood control projects to ...

OSLO, Norway, April 3--A large scale air and sea battle has been developing off the Norwegian coast since yesterday afternoon, according to reports here. Several ships and numerous planes have been observed.

Alexander Augustus Frederick William Alfred George Cambridge, first Earl of Athlone, younger brother of Queen Mary, is one of the most distinguished soldiers of the royal family. He has served in India, South Africa, France and Belgium. Since 1936 he has been personal aide de camp to his nephew, King George VI, and has lived in close touch with the royal household.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP)--A defending champion slipped from the throne and an unheralded team took the leadership in the five-man event of the American Bowling Congress tonight before one of the largest bowling crowds on record.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The House Labor Committee approved today a bill to amend the National Labor Relations Act, offered yesterday by its chairman, Representative Mary T. Norton, and instructed her to use "all possible parliamentary procedures" to have the measure considered.

MOSCOW, April 3--A writer in the Communist Youth organ Komsomblskaya Pravda today declares the session of the Japanese parliament has disappointed hopes that the new Cabinet would soon liquidate the war in China.

Stimulated by a sharp advance in securities yesterday, in addition to steadier foreign quotations, prices on the Cotton Exchange here rose 13 to 16 points under the most active trading in some time. With the technical position strengthened by recent liquidation and Bombay straddle accounts reported reduced to the lowest figures in the last two ...

MILWAUKEE, April 3--Mounting returns from yesterday's primary election in Wisconsin increased today the lead of Thomas E. Dewey, New York's District Attorney, as a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination. He apparently had won the great majority, if not all, of the State's twenty-four convention delegates, against an opposition led by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan.

After yielding two goals to their rivals within the first few minutes of play, the New York Rangers went about the task of subduing the Toronto Maple Leafs with inordinate ease at Madison Square Garden last night.

MILWAUKEE, April 3--Daniel W. Hoan, Socialist, who served as Milwaukee's Mayor for twenty-four years, was retired from office in yesterday's municipal election, defeated by a political youngster who sang for votes.

Yesterday's Cabinet shake-up in London gives further proof that Great Britain means business in the prosecution of the war. In recent weeks the British people have felt that they were not getting the driving, energetic leadership which they deserved.

Criticizing newspapers for the decline in advertising linage of certain classifications in the last ten years, William D. Nugent, vice president of Media Records, Inc., yesterday told the New York Newspaper Promotion Group luncheon

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 3-- With more than 60 per cent of the stockholders represented in person or by proxy, stockholders of the American Tobacco Company at their annual meeting here at 75 Montgomery Street today voted overwhelmingly to defeat a minority stockholders resolution which would have restricted the bonus payments to officers.

OSLO, Norway, April 3--Although warning voices continue to be raised in the Norwegian press that the danger is by no means over, all Scandinavia breathes easier today as the result of British Prime Minister Chamberlain's speech yesterday.

Net assets on each share of common stock of the General American Investors Company, Inc., on March 31 last were $11.81, the same as re ported on Dec. 31, 1939. At the end of March, 1939, they were $9.59 a share.

CINCINNATI, April 3--In contrast to the stand taken by the Seventh Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in denying a National Labor Relations Board order against the Inland Steel Company, the Sixth Circuit Court held here today that the board could compel a written contract between employer and employes in collective bargaining.

The eccentric character known to the Brooklyn murder ring as Oscar the Poet because of his love of verse was held in $50,000 bail as a material witness late yesterday after District Attorney William O'Dwyer announced that Oscar had given information concerning a gang murder and leading to the discovery in a dunk yard of parts of thirty automobiles used by the trigger men.

LONDON, April 3--The appointment of the 66-year-old Earl of Athlone, King George's uncle and Queen Mary's brother, as Governor General of Canada, succeeding Lord Tweedsmuir, who died in Montreal Feb. 11, was announced tonight.

PRAGUE, April 3--All storage batteries from automobiles, trucks and motor boats in the Protectorate that have not received a special license to operate in wartime have been confiscated by the government, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP)--Secretary Henry A. Wallace informed a House Ways and Means subcommittee today that the Department of Agriculture opposes the Patman bill to levy heavy taxes on chain stores. Secretary Wallace stated his opposition in a letter in reply to a request from Committee Chairman Robert Doughton.

The pound sterling weakened in the early trading in the free market yesterday on heavier offerings from abroad as a result of the rally in the rate on the previous day. The domestic commercial demand was no better than moderate at any ...

WASHINGTON, April 3--A Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee began today compiling a record of testimony reciting abuses in investment trusts as evidence of the need for Federal regulation proposed in a bill introduced by Senator Wagner of New York with the collaboration of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Increased purchases by the United States in Argentina and Uruguay have had little effect in easing the discriminatory exchange treatment by which both nations discourage imports from this country, exporters complained yesterday.

Winning entries in the nineteenth annual Exhibition of Advertising Art, sponsored each year by the Art Directors Club, were announced yesterday and will be previewed this afternoon at the 50 Rockefeller Plaza Galleries. The exhibit will be opened to the public starting tomorrow and will continue until April 20.

PARIS, April 3--After having debarked from the liner Manhattan at Genoa, Italy, the first group of Americans to come from the United States as volunteers to France reached Paris today to join revived World War ambulance sections of the American Field Service.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3--On the eve of the seventh Masters' golf tournament, heralding the end of the Winter jaunt for the pros and commemorating Bob Jones's grand slam of 1930, it seems to be Texas against the field, just as it used to be Jones against the field.

In deciding the changes in the government now announced the Prime Minister had in mind the desirability of making some alterations in the relations between members of the War Cabinet and Ministers not in the Cabinet who are in charge of departments of State.

Imports of undressed furs for the three months from December through February rose to $16,264,944, or more a than double the value of $8,014,054 for the corresponding months last year, according to a tabulation issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association.

PARIS, April 3--Devastation of Poland, the starving out of its populace and the deportation of its manpower to Germany--this is the plan worked out by Field Marshal Hermann Goering and being carried out by Dr. Hans Frank, Governor General of the occupied provinces, according to information given out here.
Control of the State committee of the American Labor party, its governing body, seemed last night to depend entirely on the division of its up-State members.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The House began consideration today of the War Department's 1941 Appropriation Bill, providing $785,999,094 to carry forward the national defense program.

Double victories by Erwin Rudolph and Andrew Ponzi featured yesterday's competition in the world pocket billiards championship. Rudolph topped Joseph Procita twice at Doyle's Academy and Ponzi strengthened his grip on first place by taking two games from Onofrio Lauri at Newark.
Dr. and Mrs. Ray W. Gannett of 1,710 Avenue N, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Gannett, to Maurice F. Delano Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Delano of Dedham, Mass.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3--Harvard opened a lacrosse tour by defeating Pennsylvania in an extraperiod match today, 4--2. Pete Zouck's goal in two minutes and fifty seconds after the overtime period started, clinched the victory and less than two minutes later he tallied again.

The appointment of Queen Mary's brother as Governor General will be accepted as a graceful tribute to the people of Canada. Lord Athlone and his wife, Princess Alice, are distinguished members of the royal family. They take no part in politics, no stand on controversial issues; but Canada ...
Post-Easter hats were sold at auction last night at a fashion show staged for the benefit of the United Committee for French Relief at the Hotel Actor. The sale brought about $7,000.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 3-- Monte Pearson, who pitched a nohit, no-run game for the Yankees the Summer before last, tuned himself up today for what might be another one of these performances this year when he tossed off five perfect innings against a baffled tribe of Oklahoma City Indians.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 3--In Rumanian oil quarters it is said the Germans are continuing their petroleum purchases on a large scale and that they have recently bought from one Rumanian company 47,000 tons of oil.

The anti-trust suits filed by the government through Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, against a group of labor unions and their leaders with the ostensible purpose of halting alleged restraints of trade threaten the annihilation

The National Retail Dry Goods Association will double its effort to gain retail and other business support for the principle of experience rating in unemployment insurance, the board of directors decided at a meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The State Department has asked the Daily Publishing Company, Inc., of New York, publisher of The Daily Worker, for prompt information concerning the terms of contracts with some foreign news agencies which were arranged orally in April, 1936, by Earl Browder, general sscretary of the Communist party of the United States.

Considerable comment was evoked in New York radio circles yesterday when reports circulated that James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, had demanded specific facilities at a definite time from the National Broadcasting Company for his Tuesday night broadcast warning the public against premature investment in television receivers because of the "fluid state of the art."

WASHINGTON, April 3--Secretary Wallace selected Memphis today as the first city in which to try the cotton-stamp program to supply surplus cotton goods to needy families through normal trade channels in the same way that surplus foodstuffs are going to relief families under the food-stamp plan.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 3 (AP) --Richard Truman Percy, 71 years old, New York City organist missing from his home since Mareh 20, identified himself today to a physician at the Hotel Powers and said he had been injured when a bus from which he was alighting on lower Fifth Avenue, New York, turned and threw him to the pavement.
The pamphlet report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for 1939, made public yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, president, showed a net income of $5,021,620.

PARIS, April 3--Aerial activity having moderated, the Western Front has reverted to colorless routine: "Nothing to report" and "a quiet day." For the little of glamour that is left in war is for the air force.

BERLIN, April 3--A bitter lesson has been taught to Germans by this Winter's record cold and snowfalls. In months past thousands of Germans shivered for weeks when the coal transportation system collapsed, but measures are now being taken to make sure that this will not happen again.

TRENTON, April 3--Tactics employed by the State Department of Labor in enforcing a minimum wage order in light manufacturing industries were denounced today as "persecution" by representatives of the North New Jersey Manufactuners Council. The delegation protested to Governor Moore at the capitol here.

A single prospective juror, a Negro, was seated tentatively in the jury box in the Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday as the trial of seventeen men indicted for conspiring to overthrow the government of the United States by force, and for the alleged theft of munitions and other government property, began before Judge Marcus B. Campbell.

ROME, April 3--Relations between the Vatican and Germany have deteriorated since the visit of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, to the Pope, it was admitted in a Vatican English broadcast last evening.

Last Fall we hunted quail with a man who was a novice at all forms of hunting, and although he had put in only two or three days in the field since buying his outfit, he was ready to call it a season.

WASHINGTON, April 3--An indicated weakening of Japan's economic structure, caused by the strain of the continuing war in China, was the outstanding factor reported in a survey of the economic conditions in Japan in 1939 and made public today by the Commerce Department.

LONDON, April 3--Sir Samuel Hoare, Great Britain's now Air Secretary, returns to a post he has held twice before during a long career in Parliament and the Cabinet. He was Air Secretary from 1922 to 1924 and from 1924 to 1929. He has held almost every job in the government except Prime Minister, and he has been one of the "big four" in the Cabinet ever since Neville Chamberlain became Prime Minister.

With the gala opening of the World's Fair's second season less than six weeks away, a statement of its financial position, showing total expenditures of $54,712,238 and receipts of $31,149,487, was issued yesterday and at the same time plans were announced for a muchelaborated exhibit of the Swiss Republic, which will use 10,000 additional square feet of floor space.

$185,825,233 Here From Canada Presumably to Pay for British War Supplies RECORD TOTAL SINCE 1934 Empire Accounts for Large Amounts--$13,933,885 Is Contributed by Sweden WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)--The Department of Commerce said today that $231,237,068 of gold came into the United States in the week ended on March 27, the largest amount since weekly compilations were begun in 1934.
PARIS, April 3--According to French law, employers are required to reinstate men in their employ when they at a discharged from the military service.
CLEVELAND, April 3 (AP)--An army pilot helped send two attack bombers "crashing" into, Lake Erie in mimic warfare today, then died a few hours later in hiS pursuit plane.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3-- "The Return of Frank James," sequel to last season's "Jesse James," will go before the cameras at Twentieth Century-Fox on May 15, with Fritz Lang directing, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, N.J., April 3-- The Rev. Denton M. Gerow made public today an analysis and some of the replies, including one from President Roosevelt, that he had received to a question sent to several hundred nationally prominent figures.

LINCOLN, England, April 3 (Canadian Press)--The flat-racing season got under way today when Mrs. A. Bendir's French-bred QuartierMaitre, 7-to-2 favorite, won the Lincolnshire Handicap to give Gordon Richards, England's, champion jockey for thirteen seasons, his first success at Lincoln.
LONDON, April 3--There is no question of any change in British policy on the Far East, Parliament was assured today.
WASHINGTON, April 3--President Roosevelt's projected trip to the Pacific Coast this Summer may develop into a political tour if the ...

ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP)--The Post-Dispatch was fined $2,000 and smaller fines and short jail sentences were given two executives of the newspaper today when Circuit Judge Thomas J. Rowe found them in contempt of court for criticizing in editorials and a cartoon dismissal of an extortion case in his court.

PARIS, April 3--Prison terms of five years, fines and loss of civil rights for five years were imposed today by a military court after a secret trial lasting more than a week upon thirty-six former Communist Deputies. Eight others, who fought for France in the World War, received suspended sentences of four years.

TEANECK, N.J., April 3--Miss Helen Loftus Duck, daughter of Mrs. George Francis Duck of this place and the late Mr. Duck, widely known consulting mining engineer, was married here this morning to Waldo Emerson Gentzler, bursar of Columbia University, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Gentzler of York, Pa. The Rev. William K. Russell performed the ceremony.

LONDON, April 3--Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain reshuffled his Cabinet today, giving added powers to Winston Churchill, who remains as First Lord of the Admiralty, and accepting the resignation of Lord Chatfield as Minister for Coordination of Defense. The War Cabinet is thus reduced from nine members to eight.

When Tom Pendergast leaves his cell in Leavenworth he will find only the ruins of the "invincible machine" he built in Kansas City. The complete sweep of the reform ticket has placed a Mayor and seven out of eight Councilmen in the City Hall.

Beginning Tuesday, April 30, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will make her debut as the star of a commercial radio program to be broadcast nationally twice a week for fifteen minutes over the Red Network of the National Broadcasting Company, it was announced last night.
ROME, April 3--The Fascist leaders today have resumed the attitude of watchful waiting that Italians have had to assume more than once since the war started.

Although supporters of Vice President John N. Garner for the Democratic Presidential nomination failed in their attempt to elect delegates to the Democratic National Convention in contests in four Congressional districts wholly or partly in New York City, their leading candidates in the four districts received

The Board of Transportation ratified yesterday by unanimous vote of its three members Mayor La Guardia's pledge that the city, when it takes over the Interborough and B.M.T. transit systems for municipal operation, will assume and perform the collective

PHILADELPHIA, April 3--Contending that deals between themselves prevented the stock market crash of 1929 from being worse than it was, Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob asked the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to approve the transactions and uphold their claims for deductions in income tax returns for losses.

Bernard Sanders and Gladys Schultz designed a Fifth Avenue department-store window a few months ago. They were on the sidewalk gloating over the job, when a stuffy old gentleman came by with his spouse.

With a vigor which caught many shorts napping, the stock market shot forward yesterday to the best levels of the current recovery movement, and with strong sponsorship from the steel issues, gains as high as 4 points were scored. Accompanying this sharp rally was the heaviest volume of the year on the Stock Exchange, or since Nov. 3 of last year, as 1,725,240 shares changed hands, against 834,930 on Tuesday.

Probably a majority of those who attended the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, with Igor Stravinsky as guest conductor, anticipated a rather commonplace order of interpretation from'a man who is a composer of scores which are in some instances very difficult of performance and which he has customarily left to others to interpret.

A row of eight two-story apartment and store buildings in Freeport, Nassau County, known as 282 to 296 North Main Street, has been sold by Charles M. Burtis Jr. to Pioneer Equities, Inc., an investing client of Milton Zuckerman, attorney.

PARIS, April 3--Premier Paul Reynaud, who is also Foreign Minister, received Ambassador Raffaele Guariglia of Italy and is understood to have repeated assurances given about the map shown in a photograph on the cover of the French magazine Illustration depicting M. Reynaud's conference with Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State.

The threat of a strike among roustabouts and other non-performing employes, similar to the 1938 strike that hampered the show for several days here, hung today over the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus, scheduled to open tomorrow at Madison Square Garden for a twenty-six-day stay.
Trading in the Bronx was scattered yesterday, when properties of several varieties, including a number of large apartment houses, passed into new ownership.

Miss Edith Olgivie Druce, who in 1908 amazed the aeronautical world by making a three-minute flight at Le Mons, France, with the late Wilbur Wright as her pilot, took her second flight yesterday at La Guardia Field as a guest of American Airlines.

KUNMING, China, April 3--Discoveries that represent a tremendous step forward in the treatment of leprosy, and which may prove a complete cure for the disease, were announced here today in a paper delivered at the annual meeting of the Chinese Medical Association by Dr. D.C. Nelson. He is a young American mission worker in Kiulun-kiang in Southern Yunnan, where the incidence of leprosy is high.

The old-fashioned notion that a child's life is carefree received another setback yesterday at the hands of two psychologists who found youngsters of 10 and 11 years beset by at least fifty-three worries, chief of which was failing in school tests, a worry-provoker more pressing than illness in the family or a spanking.

ROME, Ga., April 3--Closing out their business with the Atlanta Crackers in this city of the Seven Hills today, the Dodgers made it three straight by winning the finale, 6--1.

City College gave Columbia a severe battering and a bad scare in the gloom and rain at Baker Field yesterday as both teams opened their baseball seasons. But the Beavers overlooked one important item. They neglected to win the game, the Lions attending to that 7 to 6.

E.M. DELAFIELD'S Provincial, Lady, the most unprovincial-ladylike Provincial Lady in all England, has been keeping another diary.* She has been keeping it in spite of the war--or, more precisely, on account of the war.

PARIS, April 3--Premier Paul Reynaud told America tonight that "France and England are strong and strong enough to win" the war and would accept no "phoney" peace with Chancellor Hitler. France has "forged the weapon" against totalitarian Ger- ... many and "now we are going to use it," he said.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 3--New York University took advantage of five Princeton errors and nine timely hits to chalk up a 9-6 victory in its opening test of the season on University Field today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3--Paul B. Detwiler, bank official who for many years had been active, locally and nationally, in the American Institute of Banking, died of heart disease today in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He had been in ill health for three years. He was 53 years old yesterday.

CANNINGTON, Ont., April 3-- Canada's supreme task in the present conflict is to make every sacrifice short of impairing her as a sovereign nation, to bring the United States into the war on the side of the Allies, Attorney General Gordon Conant of Ontario said here tonight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 3 (AP)-- Senator Taft of Ohio, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said today in an interview that the results of the Wisconsin election "indicate a very substantial anti-Roosevelt sentiment."
Sales of small apartment buildings furnished the bulk of the trading in Brooklyn realty reported yesterday.

BERLIN, April 3--While deliveries of farm products and raw materials by Russia to Germany still are being carefully hidden by both sides, causing much guessing and speculation abroad, the best available information indicates shipments are gradually getting under way although it may still take considerable time before the quantities expected by Berlin will be reached.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 3 (AP)--Sir Damion, Marshall Field's 6-year-old that had shown little since winning the Dixie Handicap at Pimlico last Spring, finally came through at Tropical Park today in a mile and a sixteenth allowance race.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 3--The Argentine and Bolivian Foreign Ministers last night signed a treaty by which Argentina will finance construction of a railroad from her frontier to the Bolivian petroleum fields, accepting oil in payment. Bolivia already has a similar treaty with Brazil.

Fifteen-year-old Frederick McGovern, a strapping city-bred, farm hand, who ran-away from his Bronx home in 1938 and subsequently married a 19-year-old daughter of a farmer in Westfield, Mass., became yesterday the first married "man" ever held in custody in the Bronx Children's Shelter, Grand Concourse and McCleallan Street.
WASHINGTON, April 3--Unexpected strength shown by supporters blocked today a Senate vote on the amendment proposed by Senator O'Mahoney to the resolution to extend the Trade Agreements Act.

BOWIE, Md., April 3--Setting a new stake record, Honey Cloud today captured the tenth running of the Rowe Memorial Handicap, with Sun Egret and Rough Time finishing two, four behind him in a field of six. The 6-year-old gelding, who has won frequently over this holding strip, ran the six furlongs in 1:11 4-5, the fastest time here in the last three years at least.

LONDON, April 3--The brassy voice of a loudspeaker at a British airdrome told in a running story today how the first British air fighter was lost defending the coasts of England, but only after it had shot down a German Heinkel plane over the North Sea.

Influenced by the strong position taken by tanner's in resisting widespread bids for leather at concessions from their list prices, both spots and futures of cattle hides advanced yesterday, in good trading, and a substantial volume of leather buying at full tanners' lists was reported.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 3--The white and lemon ticked pointer Lakeview Farm Dusty, owned and handled by John H. Miller of Clayton, N.J., ran the outstanding race in the members derby event held by the English Setter Club of America on their home grounds near this town today.

The biggest election ever conducted by the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board will begin at 6 A.M. today when the first of 31,500 Consolidated Edison employes go to the polls to signify whether they wish to be represented in collective bargaining by a C.I.O. union, an independent union or neither.

The American foundations have grown up and, working with both their heads and their hearts, are making permanent and vital contributions in advancing science, health and civilization in this country, Dr. Frederick P. Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, told a distinguished gathering at the Academy of Medicine last night.

Encouraged by the cooperation of New Yorkers who virtually clamor to be counted, the census bureau's 8,300 enumerators in the five boroughs got into their stride yesterday and sped up probably 25 per cent over their first day on the job, according to Kirke D. Austin, area manager.

GENEVA, April 3--Considerable uneasiness was aroused here by Prime Minister Chamberlain's announcement yesterday that the Allies are determined to intensify the economic blockade of Germany. His warning to neutrals that they will have access to British products only if they guarantee to limit trade with Germany is the keynote of the speech so far as Switzerland is concerned.

SHANGHAI, April 3 (UP)--Leading American taxpayers discussed today the possibility of requesting the consular body to ask the municipal council to postpone the local elections, in view of the existence of abnormal conditions in Shanghai.

NOW the fun will be in seeing how much money the New York racing public will roll through the mutuel machines in the turf season just ahead. It will be plenty, even though it may not bring home the State tax return of $10,000,000 blithely estimated by Senator John J. Dunnigan when he set out to steer the bill through the Albany legislative machine.

Charles H. Roemer, president of the Industrial Commission of Paterson, will be the guest speaker at the luncheon of the Real Estate Board of Newark at Bamberger's Restaurant today. Mr. Roemer will discuss "How to Attract Industries."

WASHINGTON, April 3--The strength shown by Thomas E. Dewey in the Wisconsin Republican primary came as a great surprise to conservative party leaders here. Those supporting Senator Taft or Senator Vandenberg had hoped to defeat the young New Yorker in his first major battle and thereby stop him in coming primaries.

It is something of a shock to learn that "young" John D. Rockefeller, having reached the retiring age of 65, is relinquishing the chairmanship of the Board of Trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation. The Rockefeller money has been used the world over to advance human health and happiness.
Several large suites in East Side buildings were among the residential units figuring in yesterday's leasing activity.

Additions to the "conscience fund" of the New York Central Railroad dropped sharply in 1939, the company announced yesterday for whatever economic significance the fact was worth. The receipts were $93.40 in 1939, as compared with an annual average of $265 in the past five years.

HOLBROOK, L.I., April 3-- Three young brothers held in the Brentwood detention home on a variety of charges resulting from their first fling at crime learned today that their distracted mother, shortly before dawn this morning, drowned herself in a cistern behind their home.

CHICAGO, April 3--The first of the private estimates on the Winter wheat crop, issued today, confirmed the belief of the trade that there had been a moderate improvement in the general outlook as a result of favorable weather conditions late in December which continued into February.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 3 (AP)-- John B. Ryerson, the Cooperstown, N.Y., veteran, today defeated Bill Cozart of Durham, 5 and 4, in their second-round match of the annual North and South amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Seventyfive to 100 of the 350-odd members of the Young Communist League of Massachusetts are students in New England colleges and universities, Thomas F.P. O'Dea, president of the organization, told the Dies Committee investigating un-American activities today.

Will H. Hays was re-elected yesterday for the nineteenth consecutive year as president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., at its offices, 28 West Forty-fourth Street. The election had been scheduled for March 25, but was postponed for lack of a quorum.

WASHINGTON, April 3--On the Republican side, the results of the Wisconsin primary have demonstrated that Thomas E. Dewey's remarkable run against Governor Lehman in 1938 was neither a fluke nor a negative register of protest, but proof of enduring and general vote-getting powers.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP)--Willie Hoppe of New York, who clinched the world three-cushion billiard title last night, followed with another speedy performance tonight, defeating Joe Chamaco of Mexico City, 50 to 21, in thirty innings to run his undefeated string to 17.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)--The National Boxing Association offered today to sit down with its longtime foe, the New York State Athletic Commission, to work out a plan for loosening the stranglehold which it claims the New York body has on professional boxing.

BERLIN, April 3--The steady increase in prices of shares on the Boerse since the beginning of the war is causing some concern in Berlin's financial circles. Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange received yesterday letters from the committee on member firms, inviting them to present plans for incorporation of affiliates. WASHINGTON, April 5--Department store sales for the week ended on March 30 were 20 per cent below the corresponding 1939 week, which preceded Easter, and during the four-week period ended on March 30 were 1 per cent over the similar 1939 period, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The opening round in the three groups of the United States Chess Federation championship preliminaries was completed last night in the rooms of the Manhattan and Marshall Clubs. Twelve matches, four in each group, were played, without a single draw resulting.

ALBANY, April 14--For the second successive year Governor Lehman has vetoed a plan for meritrating in unemployment insurance. Under the plan employers with stable payrolls would pay lower unemployment insurance taxes than those with a large employment turnover.
